But the interest thing be that the memory itself be no well recall by the odour than by the picture .|But the interesting thing was that the memory itself was no better recalled by the odour than by the picture.

`` People do n't remember any more detail or with any more clarity when the memory be recall with an odour , ''she say .|"People don't remember any more detail or with any more clarity when the memory is recalled with an odour," she says.
`` However , with the odour , you have this intense emotional feel that's really visceral . ''|"However, with the odour, you have this intense emotional feeling that's really visceral."
That's hardly surprising , Herz think , give how the brain have evolve .|That's hardly surprising, Herz thinks, given how the brain has evolved.

`` The way I like to think about it be that emotion and olfaction be essentially the same thing , ''she say .|"The way I like to think about it is that emotion and olfaction are essentially the same thing," she says.

`` The part of the brain that control emotion literally grow out of the part of the brain that control smell . ''|"The part of the brain that controls emotion literally grew out of the part of the brain that controls smell."

That , she say , probably explains why memory for odour that be associate with intense emotion be so strongly entrench in u , because smell be initially a survival skill : a signal to approach or to avoid .|That, she says, probably explains why memories for odours that are associated with intense emotions are so strongly entrenched in us, because smell was initially a survival skill: a signal to approach or to avoid.

So , they ask them to sniff vanilla and simultaneously show them either a picture of ice cream or of cheese , while scan their brain in a fMRI machine .|So, they asked them to sniff vanilla and simultaneously showed them either a picture of ice cream or of cheese, while scanning their brains in a fMRI machine.

From the Middle Ages to the 20th century , what be the influence and movement that have shape the change face of British architecture ?|From the Middle Ages to the 20th century, what are the influences and movements that have shaped the changing face of British architecture?
Architecture be about evolution , not revolution .|Architecture is about evolution, not revolution.

It use to be thought that once the Romans pull out of Britain in the fifth century , their elegant villa , carefully-planned town and engineering marvel like Hadrian's Wall simply fell into decay a British culture be plunge into the Dark Ages .|It used to be thought that once the Romans pulled out of Britain in the fifth century, their elegant villas, carefully-planned towns and engineering marvels like Hadrian's Wall simply fell into decay as British culture was plunged into the Dark Ages.

It take the Norman Conquest of 1 066 to bring back the light , and the Gothic cathedral-builders of the Middle Ages played an important part in the revival of British culture .|It took the Norman Conquest of 1 066 to bring back the light, and the Gothic cathedral-builders of the Middle Ages played an important part in the revival of British culture.
However , the truth be not a simple a that .|However, the truth is not as simple as that.

Romano-British culture—and that include architecture along with language , religion , political organisation and the arts—survived long after the Roman withdrawal .|Romano-British culture—and that included architecture along with language, religion, political organisation and the arts—survived long after the Roman withdrawal.

And although the Anglo-Saxons have a sophisticated building style of their own , little survives to bear witness to their achievement a the vast majority of Anglo- Saxon building be make of wood .|And although the Anglo-Saxons had a sophisticated building style of their own, little survives to bear witness to their achievements as the vast majority of Anglo- Saxon buildings were made of wood.

Even so , the period between the Norman land at Pevensey in 1066 and the day in 1485 when Richard III lose his horse and his head at Bosworth , usher in the Tudors and the Early Modern period , mark a rare flower of British building .|Even so, the period between the Norman landing at Pevensey in 1066 and the day in 1485 when Richard III lost his horse and his head at Bosworth, ushering in the Tudors and the Early Modern period, marks a rare flowering of British buildings.

And it be all the more remarkable because the underlie ethos of medieval architecture be `` fitness for purpose '' .|And it is all the more remarkable because the underlying ethos of medieval architecture was "fitness for purpose".
The great cathedral and parish church that lift up their tower to heaven be not only act of devotion in stone
column2: they be also fiercely functional building .|The great cathedrals and parish churches that lifted up their towers to heaven were not only acts of devotion in stone
column3: they were also fiercely functional buildings.

column1: Castles serve their particular purpose and their battlement and turret be for use rather than ornament .|Castles served their particular purpose and their battlements and turrets were for use rather than ornament.

The ramble manor house of the later Middle Ages , however , be primarily home , their owner achieve respect and maintain status by their hospitality and good lordship rather than the grandeur of their building .|The rambling manor houses of the later Middle Ages, however, were primarily homes, their owners achieving respect and maintaining status by their hospitality and good lordship rather than the grandeur of their buildings.

In a sense , the building of the 16th century be also govern by fitness for purpose—only now , the purpose be very different .|In a sense, the buildings of the 16th century were also governed by fitness for purpose—only now, the purpose was very different.
In domestic architecture , in particular , building be use to display status and wealth .|In domestic architecture, in particular, buildings were used to display status and wealth.
This stately and curious workmanship show itself in various way .|This stately and curious workmanship showed itself in various ways.

A great sense of security lead to more outward-looking building , a oppose to the medieval arrangement where the need for defence create house that face inward onto a courtyard or series of courtyard .|A greater sense of security led to more outward-looking buildings, as opposed to the medieval arrangement where the need for defence created houses that faced inward onto a courtyard or series of courtyards.
This allow for much more in the way of exterior ornament .|This allowed for much more in the way of exterior ornament.

The room themselves tend to be big and lighter—as an expensive commodity , the use of great expanse of glass be in itself a statement of wealth .|The rooms themselves tended to be bigger and lighter—as an expensive commodity, the use of great expanses of glass was in itself a statement of wealth.
There be also a general move towards balance and symmetrical exterior with central entrance .|There was also a general move towards balanced and symmetrical exteriors with central entrances.

With the exception of Inigo Jones ( 1573-1652 ) , whose confident handle of classical detail and proportion set him apart from all other architect of the period , most early 1 7th century building tend to take the innocent exuberance of late Tudor work one step far .|With the exception of Inigo Jones (1573-1652), whose confident handling of classical detail and proportion set him apart from all other architects of the period, most early 1 7th century buildings tended to take the innocent exuberance of late Tudor work one step further.

But during the 1640s and 50 the Civil War and it aftermath sent many gentleman and noble to the Continent either to escape the fight or , when the war be lose , to follow Charles II into exile .|But during the 1640s and 50s the Civil War and its aftermath sent many gentlemen and nobles to the Continent either to escape the fighting or, when the war was lost, to follow Charles II into exile.

There they come into contact with French , Dutch and Italian architecture and , with Charles's restoration in 1 660 , there be a flurry of building activity a royalist reclaim their property and built themselves house reflect the late European trend .|There they came into contact with French, Dutch and Italian architecture and, with Charles's restoration in 1 660, there was a flurry of building activity as royalists reclaimed their property and built themselves houses reflecting the latest European trends.

The British Baroque be a reassertion of authority , an expression of absolutist ideology by men who remember a world turn upside down during the Civil War .|The British Baroque was a reassertion of authority, an expression of absolutist ideology by men who remembered a world turned upside down during the Civil War.
The style be heavy and rich , sometimes overblown and melodramatic .|The style is heavy and rich, sometimes overblown and melodramatic.
The politics which underpin it be questionable , but it product be breathtaking .|The politics which underpin it are questionable, but its products are breathtaking.

The huge glass-and-iron Crystal Palace , design by Joseph Paxton to house the Great Exhibition of 1851 , show another strand to 19th century architecture—one which embrace new industrial process .|The huge glass-and-iron Crystal Palace, designed by Joseph Paxton to house the Great Exhibition of 1851, shows another strand to 19th century architecture—one which embraced new industrial processes.
But it be n't long before even this confidence in progress come to be regard with suspicion .|But it wasn't long before even this confidence in progress came to be regarded with suspicion.

Mass production result in building and furnishing that be too perfect , a the individual craftsman no longer have a major role in their creation .|Mass production resulted in buildings and furnishings that were too perfect, as the individual craftsman no longer had a major role in their creation.

Railing against the dehumanise effect of industrialisation , reformer like John Ruskin and William Morris make a concert effort to return to hand-crafted , pre-industrial manufacturing technique .|Railing against the dehumanising effects of industrialisation, reformers like John Ruskin and William Morris made a concerted effort to return to hand-crafted, pre-industrial manufacturing techniques.

Morris's influence grow from the production of furniture and textile , until by the 1880s a generation of principled young architect be follow his call for good , honest construction .|Morris's influence grew from the production of furniture and textiles, until by the 1880s a generation of principled young architects was following his call for good, honest construction.
The most important trend in early 20th century architecture simply pas Britain by .|The most important trends in early 20th century architecture simply passed Britain by.

Whilst Gropius be work on cold , hard expanse of glass , and Le Corbusier be experiment with the use of reinforce concrete frame , we have staid establishment architect like Edwin Lutyens produce Neo-Georgian and Renaissance country house for an outmode land class .|Whilst Gropius was working on cold, hard expanses of glass, and Le Corbusier was experimenting with the use of reinforced concrete frames, we had staid establishment architects like Edwin Lutyens producing Neo-Georgian and Renaissance country houses for an outmoded landed class.

In addition there be slightly batty architect- craftsman , the heir of William Morris , still try to turn the clock back to before the Industrial Revolution by make chair and spurn new technology .|In addition there were slightly batty architect- craftsmen, the heirs of William Morris, still trying to turn the clock back to before the Industrial Revolution by making chairs and spurning new technology.

Only a handful of Modern Movement building of any real merit be produce here during the 1920s and 1930s , and most of these be the work of foreign architect such a Serge Chermayeff , Berthold Lubetkin and Erno Gold-finger who have settle in this country .|Only a handful of Modern Movement buildings of any real merit were produced here during the 1920s and 1930s, and most of these were the work of foreign architects such as Serge Chermayeff, Berthold Lubetkin and Erno Gold-finger who had settled in this country.
After the Second World War the situation begin to change .|After the Second World War the situation began to change.

The Modern Movement's belief in progress and the future struck a chord with the mood of post-war Britain and , a reconstruction begin under Attlee's Labour government in 1 945 , there be a desperate need for cheap housing which could be produce quickly .|The Modern Movement's belief in progress and the future struck a chord with the mood of post-war Britain and, as reconstruction began under Attlee's Labour government in 1 945, there was a desperate need for cheap housing which could be produced quickly.

The use of prefabricate element , metal frame , concrete cladding and the absence of decoration—all of which have be embrace by Modernists abroad and view with suspicion by the British—were adopt to vary degree for housing development and school .|The use of prefabricated elements, metal frames, concrete cladding and the absence of decoration—all of which had been embraced by Modernists abroad and viewed with suspicion by the British—were adopted to varying degrees for housing developments and schools.

Local authority , charge with the task of rebuild city centre , become important patron of architecture .|Local authorities, charged with the task of rebuilding city centres, became important patrons of architecture.

This represent a shift away from the private individual who have dominate the architectural scene for century .|This represented a shift away from the private individuals who had dominated the architectural scene for centuries.

Since the War it have be corporate body like these local authority , together with national and multinational company , and large educational institution , which have dominate British architecture .|Since the War it has been corporate bodies like these local authorities, together with national and multinational companies, and large educational institutions, which have dominated British architecture.

By the late 1 980s the Modern Movement , unfairly blame for the social experiment implicit in high-rise housing , have lose out to irony and spectacle in the shape of post-modernism , with it cheerful borrowing from anywhere and any period .|By the late 1 980s the Modern Movement, unfairly blamed for the social experiments implicit in high-rise housing, had lost out to irony and spectacle in the shape of post-modernism, with its cheerful borrowings from anywhere and any period.
But now , in the new Millennium , even post-modernism be show sign of age .|But now, in the new Millennium, even post-modernism is showing signs of age.
What come next ?|What comes next?

Not long after that , Perkin make the scientific breakthrough that would bring him both fame and fortune .|Not long after that, Perkin made the scientific breakthrough that would bring him both fame and fortune.
At the time , quinine be the only viable medical treatment for malaria .|At the time, quinine was the only viable medical treatment for malaria.

During his vacation in 1856 , Perkin spent his time in the laboratory on the top floor of his family 's house .|During his vacation in 1856, Perkin spent his time in the laboratory on the top floor of his family’s house.

He be attempt to manufacture quinine from aniline , an inexpensive and readily available coal tar waste product .|He was attempting to manufacture quinine from aniline, an inexpensive and readily available coal tar waste product .

This have lead some to wonder whether Pollock's work feel so dynamic because the brain reconstructs the energetic action the artist use a he paint .|This has led some to wonder whether Pollock's works feel so dynamic because the brain reconstructs the energetic actions the artist used as he painted.
This may be down to our brain's 'mirror neuron ' , which be know to mimic others ' action .|This may be down to our brain's 'mirror neurons', which are known to mimic others' actions.
The hypothesis will need to be thoroughly test , however .|The hypothesis will need to be thoroughly tested, however.

It might even be the case that we could use neuroaesthetic study to understand the longevity of some piece of artwork .|It might even be the case that we could use neuroaesthetic studies to understand the longevity of some pieces of artwork.

While the fashion of the time might shape what be currently popular , work that be best adapt to our visual system may be the most likely to linger once the trend of previous generation have be forgotten .|While the fashions of the time might shape what is currently popular, works that are best adapted to our visual system may be the most likely to linger once the trends of previous generations have been forgotten.

It's still early day for the field of neuroaesthetics - and these study be probably only a taste of what be to come .|It's still early days for the field of neuroaesthetics - and these studies are probably only a taste of what is to come.
It would , however , be foolish to reduce art appreciation to a set of scientific law .|It would, however, be foolish to reduce art appreciation to a set of scientific laws.

We should n't underestimate the importance of the style of a particular artist , their place in history and the artistic environment of their time .|We shouldn't underestimate the importance of the style of a particular artist, their place in history and the artistic environment of their time.
Abstract art offer both a challenge and the freedom to play with different interpretation .|Abstract art offers both a challenge and the freedom to play with different interpretations.

In some way , it's not so different to science , where we be constantly look for system and decode meaning so that we can view and appreciate the world in a new way .|In some ways, it's not so different to science, where we are constantly looking for systems and decoding meaning so that we can view and appreciate the world in a new way.

be there for a couple day and we be able to catch up over sushi , cornbread and soup at Whole Foods in Columbus Circle .|was there for a couple days and we were able to catch up over sushi, cornbread and soup at Whole Foods in Columbus Circle.

I ’ m glad I didn ’ t order any beef because it look like those who do get a plate of gristly rubber .|I’m glad I didn’t order any beef because it looked like those who did got a plate of gristly rubber.

We lament that a expensive a it be to go up the mountain , it would be more expensive to go down — you have the option of take to the park exit a helicopter ( at $ 800 per person , or nothing if the doctor thought your condition require immediate evacuation ) , a mule or a 2-3 day walk , after which you have to pay for a shuttle to Mendoza and lodge in Mendoza upon arrival .|We lamented that as expensive as it was to go up the mountain, it would be more expensive to go down — you had the option of taking to the park exit a helicopter (at $800 per person, or nothing if the doctor thought your condition required immediate evacuation), a mule or a 2-3 day walk, after which you had to pay for a shuttle to Mendoza and lodging in Mendoza upon arrival.

We be a spirit group , and I think we be all happy that we get along so well , notwithstanding our size .|We were a spirited group, and I think we were all happy that we got along so well, notwithstanding our size.

However , our spirit be somewhat dampen by news that 5 people from 2 different expedition have die on the mountain during our stay at base camp .|However, our spirits were somewhat dampened by news that 5 people from 2 different expeditions had died on the mountain during our stay at base camp.
It remind u about the seriousness of the climb .|It reminded us about the seriousness of the climb.
During the week we spent above base camp , I have altitude headache and nausea on and off .|During the week we spent above base camp, I had altitude headaches and nausea on and off.

I try sleep , propped up against the side of my tent near the flap a ) so that I could unzip and lean my head out if I need to vomit and b ) in the hope that it would keep those nightly splitting headache at bay .|I tried sleeping, propped up against the side of my tent near the flap a) so that I could unzip and lean my head out if I needed to vomit and b) in the hopes that it would keep those nightly splitting headaches at bay.

It turn out I didn ’ t actually vomit and those splitting headache be bullish about come on in the middle of the night .|It turned out I didn’t actually vomit and those splitting headaches were bullish about coming on in the middle of the night.

When I look at my photo , I found that I ’ d hardly take any above base camp , and I ’ d take none after Camp 2 .|When I looked at my photos, I found that I’d hardly taken any above base camp, and I’d taken none after Camp 2.

Luckily , my tentmates , Emilia and Frances , kept me entertain , and thus mostly distract from the discomfort .|Luckily, my tentmates, Emilia and Frances, kept me entertained, and thus mostly distracted from the discomfort.

I don ’ t know what I ’ d have do without Emilia 's blue pill : ) I wasn ’ t the only one suffer , though .|I don’t know what I’d have done without Emilia’s blue pills :) I wasn’t the only one suffering, though.

The remain Australian in our group after Camp 1 , would , apparently , sit up all night because he couldn ’ t breathe when he lay down .|The remaining Australian in our group after Camp 1, would, apparently, sit up all night because he couldn’t breathe when he lay down.

Max , the Swiss , sound like he might go into convulsion any time he enter or exit his tent , or when he ’ d wash his plate in the river .|Max, the Swiss, sounded like he might go into convulsions any time he entered or exited his tent, or when he’d wash his plate in the river.

Others in the group be also experience headache , but all of u be able and determine to continue ascend , so we soldier up to Camp 3 .|Others in the group were also experiencing headaches, but all of us were able and determined to continue ascending, so we soldiered up to Camp 3.
On the first summit morning , it be windy and cold .|On the first summit morning, it was windy and cold.

After check the weather report and talk to some people who be come down the trail , Ariel consult our group , who agree that we might want to avoid the cold windy summit this day and conserve our energy in order to make another attempt the next day .|After checking the weather report and talking to some people who were coming down the trail, Ariel consulted our group, who agreed that we might want to avoid the cold windy summit this day and conserve our energy in order to make another attempt the next day.

The next morning , however , only Max want to get out of his tent and while the rest of u walk down to Plaza de Mulas , he and Ariel summit .|The next morning, however, only Max wanted to get out of his tent and while the rest of us walked down to Plaza de Mulas, he and Ariel summited.

Actually , I didn ’ t walk a much a I provide entertainment for the group by fall about 35 time — it be the only section of the climb that I be carry all of my pack and at that altitude I could barely stand up , much le walk on a steep , snow-packed decline , with it on .|Actually, I didn’t walk as much as I provided entertainment for the group by falling about 35 times — it was the only section of the climb that I was carrying all of my pack and at that altitude I could barely stand up, much less walk on a steep, snow-packed decline, with it on.

Juan , the other assistant guide , have to save my butt by add my pack on top of his already huge one for most of the way down to Plaza de Mulas .|Juan, the other assistant guide, had to save my butt by adding my pack on top of his already huge one for most of the way down to Plaza de Mulas.

That it sustain my travel financially and lead me to develop a community of traveller and reader who support my work was… well , very delightful .|That it sustained my travels financially and led me to develop a community of travellers and readers who supported my work was… well, very delightful.
Very humble .|Very humbling.
How do these smart , capable people become interested in my site ?|How did these smart, capable people become interested in my site?
Reader meetups be a wondrous marvel .|Reader meetups were a wondrous marvel.
I didn ’ t know how they get there .|I didn’t know how they got there.
I just felt grateful .|I just felt grateful.
Long-term Legal Nomads fan know that I never quit my job a a lawyer because I burn out .|Long-term Legal Nomads fans know that I never quit my job as a lawyer because I burned out.
I quit because I want to see the world , and let those memory inform my next step a an attorney .|I quit because I wanted to see the world, and let those memories inform my next steps as an attorney.
That I have the privilege to do so be never lose on me .|That I had the privilege to do so was never lost on me.

Taken together , that privilege plus my profound awe that I mistakenly stumble into a passion that become a career , meant that most of my day take little for grant .|Taken together, that privilege plus my profound awe that I mistakenly stumbled into a passion that became a career, meant that most of my days took little for granted.
And then this leak happen .|And then this leak happened.
When I look back , I feel a loss of innocence .|When I look back, I feel a loss of innocence.
How could I have know to also be grateful for the ability to tie my own shoe ?|How could I have known to also be grateful for the ability to tie my own shoes?
To walk down the street without fear of someone bumping into me and reverse my fragile heal ?|To walk down the street without fear of someone bumping into me and reversing my fragile healing?

I write about be in pain since I get dengue fever , and along the edge of that pain I found a deeper appreciation for my work and my life .|I wrote about being in pain since I got dengue fever, and along the edges of that pain I found a deeper appreciation for my work and my life.
At the time , it felt that my world be narrow beyond recognition for each .|At the time, it felt that my world was narrowing beyond recognition for each.
It take adjustment to recalibrate to gratitude .|It took adjustment to recalibrate to gratitude.
With the perspective I have now , those year feel ethereal and free .|With the perspective I have now, those years feel ethereal and free.

That journey toward grace , and my earlier reacquaintance with food when I learn I be a celiac , both feel expansive in retrospect .|That journey toward grace, and my earlier reacquaintance with food when I learned I was a celiac, both feel expansive in retrospect.
I remember this column when I begin to write this post .|I remembered this column when I began to write this post.
Those time where the future felt roar and new be curiously hard to grasp .|Those times where the future felt roaring and new are curiously hard to grasp.

With the weight of tragedy , I ’ m not alone in struggle to reconcile who I be with how my heart and soul have evolve .|With the weight of tragedy, I’m not alone in struggling to reconcile who I was with how my heart and soul has evolved.
The future may have an ancient heart , but my present do too .|The future may have an ancient heart, but my present does too.

In the two year since this spinal leak begin , my inbox overflow regularly with the rattle confusion that accompanies deep misfortune .|In the two years since this spinal leak began, my inbox overflowed regularly with the rattled confusion that accompanies deep misfortune.

And I write those people back use my thumb and I say , “ Yes – what we actually know in our heart feel murky in the midst of unfathomable disorientation .|And I write those people back using my thumbs and I say, “Yes – what we actually know in our hearts feels murky in the midst of unfathomable disorientation.
Yes .|Yes.
I hear you .|I hear you.
I ’ m sorry .|I’m sorry.
I ’ m listening. ” How do you trust your heart when you can ’ t put on your own sock ?|I’m listening.”
How do you close your eye and be you when “ you ” no longer exists in some fundamental way ?|How do you close your eyes and be you when “you” no longer exists in some fundamental way?

The catastrophe lead each of u to this mysterious place where nothing make any sense always fails to provide the way out .|The catastrophe led each of us to this mysterious place where nothing makes any sense always fails to provide the way out.
The cold truth be that life just isn ’ t fair .|The cold truth is that life just isn’t fair.
Depending on our childhood , we learn that lesson early .|Depending on our childhoods, we learn that lesson early.
Or , we learn it later .|Or, we learn it later.
Eventually , we figure it out .|Eventually, we figure it out.

How we deal with the stoic certainty of that unfairness a it churn through u dictate how well we survive .|How we deal with the stoic certainty of that unfairness as it churns through us dictates how well we survive.
In those two year , I 've come to believe what many before me have say .|In those two years, I’ve come to believe what many before me have said.
That way out be through .|That way out is through.
The way out be remember what we be outside the bound of our wound .|The way out is remembering what we are outside the bounds of our wounds.
In a society ob with do , identity often tie to your accomplishment , not who you be .|In a society obsessed with doing, identity often ties to your accomplishments, not who you are.

Fighting through all that “ do ” to get to the “ be ” sometimes feel like a salmon try to swim upstream .|Fighting through all that “doing” to get to the “being” sometimes feels like a salmon trying to swim upstream.
My life today life be life itty bitty teeny tiny through no fault of my own .|My life today life is life itty bitty teeny tiny through no fault of my own.
Many week I can not go outside .|Many weeks I cannot go outside.
I be not alone in this place
column2: I have found others with similar , persistent CSF leak and similar complication follow treatment .|I am not alone in this place

column1: Together we hold ourselves aloft in the ether .|Together we hold ourselves aloft in the ether.
As I 've write before , get through this be not about think positive for me .|As I’ve written before, getting through this is not about thinking positive for me.
It 's about choose what serf this journey best .|It’s about choosing what serves this journey best.
Anger corrodes , and the last thing I need be more of that .|Anger corrodes, and the last thing I need is more of that.

It have take a conscious shift to force myself past the border of reasonable reaction , and into something open-hearted .|It has taken a conscious shift to force myself past the borders of reasonable reaction, and into something open-hearted.

To accept this twist lot I 've receive , and then transform those fiery feeling into something lighter and more empower .|To accept this twisted lot I’ve received, and then transform those fiery feelings into something lighter and more empowering.
A wisp of life be what I have , sure .|A wisp of life is what I have, sure.
But my work each day be to find joy in that wisp .|But my work each day is to find joy in that wisp.

Or put another way : I can ’ t change what happen now , but I can change the way I wake up each day .|Or put another way: I can’t change what happened now, but I can change the way I wake up each day.

Moment to moment , I have have to pull out my most powerful emotion-microscope to find way to feel gratitude despite how much I grieve .|Moment to moment, I have had to pull out my most powerful emotion-microscope to find ways to feel gratitude despite how much I grieve.

I have many tool that have help me calibrate that microscope , and I absolutely could not have do it alone .|I have many tools that have helped me calibrate that microscope, and I absolutely could not have done it alone.

I also could not have dedicate so much brainpower and time to overcome the mental aspect of this big life change without my family hold the weight of my physical care .|I also could not have dedicated so much brainpower and time to overcoming the mental aspect of this big life change without my family holding the weight of my physical care.
The “ how to stay sane within tragedy ” be a question I receive each day from reader .|The “how to stay sane within tragedy” is a question I receive each day from readers.
I hope to write about it when my health allows .|I hope to write about it when my health allows.
It 's one of the most important question we can ask , even in the absence of calamity .|It’s one of the most important questions we can ask, even in the absence of calamity.

Every day , the choice loom : do we dust ourselves off and try to find joy , or do we wallow in suffer ?|Every day, the choice looms: do we dust ourselves off and try to find joy, or do we wallow in suffering?
It 's a decision we all have to make .|It’s a decision we all have to make.
I use to think that optimize for joy alone meant that we be neglect the reason for suffer .|I used to think that optimizing for joy alone meant that we were neglecting the reasons for suffering.
I equate the shift in think to bury my head in the sand .|I equated the shift in thinking to burying my head in the sand.

Through this experience , I see that even when we have good reason to wallow , it doesn ’ t help u endure or overcome .|Through this experience, I see that even when we have good reason to wallow, it doesn’t help us endure or overcome.
My stake feel particularly acute , since most of my day be spent to myself .|My stakes feel particularly acute, since most of my days are spent to myself.
I first have to accept the intrinsic unfairness .|I first had to accept the intrinsic unfairness.

Slowly now , I can untangle the knot of my frustration and despair , and flatten out the thread until it look sleek .|Slowly now, I can untangle the knots of my frustration and despair, and flatten out the thread until it looks sleek.
Neat and tidy .|Neat and tidy.
And then the next day , I start all over again .|And then the next day, I start all over again.
This picture be a generous gift from my friend Marie-Christine .|This picture was a generous gift from my friend Marie-Christine.
A wedding photographer , she come over to shoot photo and make me feel glamorous for my 40th .|A wedding photographer, she came over to shoot photos and make me feel glamorous for my 40th.
I put on makeup for the first time in almost a year , go on the balcony , and MC do her thing .|I put on makeup for the first time in almost a year, went on the balcony, and MC did her thing.

A wise person once told me decade ago that it be smart never to compare my inside to someone else 's outside .|A wise person once told me decades ago that it was smart never to compare my insides to someone else’s outsides.
Few people wear their struggle on their sleeve or their face .|Few people wear their struggles on their sleeve or their face.
We never know someone 's story , we can ’ t say what be weigh them down or lift them up .|We never know someone’s story, we can’t say what is weighing them down or lifting them up.

We use our own belief , hone with however many year of bias , to make a judgement call about a stranger .|We use our own beliefs, honed with however many years of bias, to make a judgement call about a stranger.
It doesn ’ t look like I spent 10 month in bed or that my brain be sinking into my spine , do it ?|It doesn’t look like I spent 10 months in bed or that my brain is sinking into my spine, does it?
There 's a reason they call it “ invisible illness ” .|There’s a reason they call it “invisible illness”.
It 's one of 30 photo I ’ m set to receive , all take last week .|It’s one of 30 photos I’m set to receive, all taken last week.
My smile and laughter be real .|My smile and laughter are real.

I have an excellent afternoon with a dear friend , even though I paid for be upright with some extra pain .|I had an excellent afternoon with a dear friend, even though I paid for being upright with some extra pain.

The afternoon be a reminder of what I 've try to remember a I pa through this extraordinary time .|The afternoon was a reminder of what I’ve tried to remember as I pass through this extraordinary time.

That each moment we get with someone we love , each second that we can find goodness and joy — that 's one moment we aren ’ t give into what exists and can dredge u down .|That each moment we get with someone we love, each second that we can find goodness and joy — that’s one moment we aren’t giving into what exists and can dredge us down.

“ As my face change , I will lose myself , ” writes Chelsea G. Summers in a piece about the skincare industry .|“As my face changes, I will lose myself,” writes Chelsea G. Summers in a piece about the skincare industry.

“ The skin-deep existential crisis be this : Who be I when I don ’ t recognize myself in my own skin ? ” As a woman , age unfurls all sort of whisper consequence .|“The skin-deep existential crisis is this: Who am I when I don’t recognize myself in my own skin?”
As a woman, aging unfurls all sorts of whispered consequences.
Peeking grey hair and wrinkle and yes , change skin .|Peeking grey hair and wrinkles and yes, changing skin.
These day , age be somewhere in a storage space at the back of my mind .|These days, aging is somewhere in a storage space at the back of my mind.
At forefront be instead the dearth of basic that I never thought I ’ d lack .|At forefront is instead the dearth of basics that I never thought I’d lack.
Walking .|Walking.
Being able to tie my own shoe or cut my own toenail .|Being able to tie my own shoes or cut my own toenails.
Opening a heavy drawer .|Opening a heavy drawer.
Cooking my own food .|Cooking my own food.
Laughing hard or cough or sneeze without worry about opening up a big leak in my spine .|Laughing hard or coughing or sneezing without worrying about opening up a bigger leak in my spine.
It 's not be an easy few year .|It’s not been an easy few years.
It 's be the hardest few year , harder than I ever thought I could sustain .|It’s been the hardest few years, harder than I ever thought I could sustain.
I haven ’ t give up , and have surprised myself with the resilience I need to power through .|I haven’t given up, and have surprised myself with the resilience I needed to power through.
“ I couldn ’ t do what you 'redo , ” people tell me .|“I couldn’t do what you’re doing,” people tell me.
Of course they could .|Of course they could.

We never know the depth of our own adaptability and strength until it 's deeply call into question .|We never know the depths of our own adaptability and strength until it’s deeply called into question.
My story be no exception , it 's just a story of extreme .|My story is no exception, it’s just a story of extremes.
Freedom to not-freedom , with the love of the world in between .|Freedom to not-freedom, with the love of the world in between.
Learning a much a I could power my life a a traveler , and it 's power my life now .|Learning as much as I could powered my life as a traveler, and it’s powering my life now.

I 've spent two year reading everything I could about neuroplasticity , immunology , and epigenetics .|I’ve spent two years reading everything I could about neuroplasticity, immunology, and epigenetics.
I 've meditate more than be reasonable .|I’ve meditated more than is reasonable.

Through force of imagination and curiosity , and with the help of many remarkable people , I ’ m no longer in the pit .|Through force of imagination and curiosity, and with the help of many remarkable people, I’m no longer in the pit.
Even though I don ’ t know when I ’ ll walk again without brain sag .|Even though I don’t know when I’ll walk again without brain sag.
There be thousand and thousand of people who have show me they care during this absurd time .|There are thousands and thousands of people who have shown me they care during this absurd time.
I try to show up for other leaker in the same way , or for reader who be scar about their pain .|I try to show up for other leakers in the same way, or for readers who are scared about their pain.

I dread my 40th for the last while because my plan be for year to summit a big mountain with my friend .|I dreaded my 40th for the last while because my plan was for years to summit a big mountain with my friends.
But a the day approach , I make more peace with where I be .|But as the day approached, I made more peace with where I am.
Is it where I want to be ?|Is it where I wanted to be?
Absolutely not .|Absolutely not.

But the same lust for life that fuel my too-young-to-be-lawyering year and my eating-all-of-the-soup year sustains me now .|But the same lust for life that fuelled my too-young-to-be-lawyering years and my eating-all-of-the-soup years sustains me now.

Life change in an instant , and I feel proud that I packed in more in my 40 year than many people get in a lifetime .|Life changes in an instant, and I feel proud that I packed in more in my 40 years than many people get in a lifetime.

For the last two year , I 've have to live life from the inside-out , search for answer that don ’ t exist .|For the last two years, I’ve had to live life from the inside-out, searching for answers that don’t exist.
Trying to keep my brain afloat both literally and figuratively .|Trying to keep my brain afloat both literally and figuratively.
To be clear , she chose the message not me .|To be clear, she chose the message not me.
But it be both hilarious and delicious , and I save some of it for future consumption .|But it was both hilarious and delicious, and I saved some of it for future consumption.
I go to bed content on my 40th .|I went to bed content on my 40th.
Even without the food I use to ob over , I felt sate .|Even without the foods I used to obsess over, I felt sated.
And most of all , I felt deeply care for .|And most of all, I felt deeply cared for.
Many of u have a hard time receive love , and that 's be a lesson for me in the past two year .|Many of us have a hard time receiving love, and that’s been a lesson for me in the past two years.

It 's hard not to feel unworthy – not of love generally , but the fierceness and care of so many who want to see me well .|It’s hard not to feel unworthy – not of love generally, but the fierceness and care of so many who want to see me well.

The natural awkwardness of that feel be far eclipse by the strength it give me , and the humble effect the support have .|The natural awkwardness of that feeling is far eclipsed by the strength it gives me, and the humbling effect the support has.

I 've always look young , something that be a liability a a lawyer and a source of mirth a a traveler .|I’ve always looked young, something that was a liability as a lawyer and a source of mirth as a traveler.
But now , it feel particularly off-key .|But now, it feels particularly off-key.
When I first arrive in New York a a summer associate I be 20 .|When I first arrived in New York as a summer associate I was 20.
Amazed I be there at all , I would scrutinize people 's face a they pas by .|Amazed I was there at all, I would scrutinize people’s faces as they passed by.
Who would I look like ?|Who would I look like?
Where would my life lead me in 20 year time ?|Where would my life lead me in 20 years time?
It 's always fascinate to remember the shape of those prediction in retrospect .|It’s always fascinating to remember the shape of those predictions in retrospect.
I look at my face and my face doesn ’ t look forty .|I look at my face and my face doesn’t look forty.
I look at my face and think , who care how old my face look ?|I look at my face and think, who cares how old my face looks?

In that 2011 Rumpus column , Strayed writes about the interstitial year between know your heart 's path and make it there , eventually .|In that 2011 Rumpus column, Strayed writes about the interstitial years between knowing your heart’s path and making it there, eventually.

Many of you have ask about way to support me at a time where I can ’ t physically work the way I use to .|Many of you have asked about ways to support me at a time where I can’t physically work the way I used to.
Patreon be a great way to do so .|Patreon is a great way to do so.
I release my Patreon to the world during the last week of February .|I released my Patreon to the world during the last week of February.

For those unfamiliar with Patreon , it 's a membership platform that allows people to sign up to receive update , behind the scene video , private podcasts and more from their favourite creatives , writer , or artist .|For those unfamiliar with Patreon, it’s a membership platform that allows people to sign up to receive updates, behind the scenes videos, private podcasts and more from their favourite creatives, writers, or artists.

A lot of you in this community have suggest I start one up , and in my tiny work increment I be able to get it up and run .|A lot of you in this community have suggested I start one up, and in my tiny working increments I was able to get it up and running.

Many of my travel blogging peer have start one , but my Patreon be a bit different than the norm , because it 's support only .|Many of my travel blogging peers have started one, but my Patreon is a bit different than the norm, because it’s support only.

So instead of each tier offering more and more reward for what you sign up for , my campaign have each tier receive the same access and benefit a the others .|So instead of each tier offering more and more rewards for what you sign up for, my campaign has each tier receiving the same access and benefits as the others.
But !|But!

Unlike many support-only Patreons , it still do have fun goody ( below ) , because there be still many fun thing I can provide within my limited state .|Unlike many support-only Patreons, it still does have fun goodies (below), because there are still many fun things I can provide within my limited state.

I structure it this way because pain limit my day to day output so much that I ’ d rather be absolutely sure that I can deliver what I promise , vs. create high monetary tier and break that promise .|I structured it this way because pain limits my day to day output so much that I’d rather be absolutely sure that I can deliver what I promise, vs. creating high monetary tiers and break that promise.
It 's an amaze feel to have a community of people ask to support me from far flung place .|It’s an amazing feeling to have a community of people asking to support me from far flung places.

I 've have artist and photographer reach out a well , to provide monthly goody that I can add to the tier — mostly bird-related or soup-related , which seem about right !|I’ve had artists and photographers reach out as well, to provide monthly goodies that I can add to the tiers — mostly bird-related or soup-related, which seems about right!
The launch video be below .|The launch video is below.
Patreon page be here .|Patreon page is here.
We 'reup to about 170 people now , at the time of write .|We’re up to about 170 people now, at the time of writing.
I be never one of those “ I ’ m go to write 4000 word every morning ” people .|I was never one of those “I’m going to write 4000 words every morning” people.

Unless I be under deadline , my write held the same kind of whimsy a my travel : when inspiration struck , I pounce .|Unless I was under deadline, my writing held the same kind of whimsy as my travels: when inspiration struck, I pounced.
And then I basically go feral .|And then I basically went feral.

When the tingly , “ I need to write ” feel start , I knew I need to stock up on snack , get a shower in now , and cancel plan with friend .|When the tingly, “I need to write” feeling started, I knew I needed to stock up on snacks, get a shower in now, and cancel plans with friends.
I would forget to eat , live , and do day-to-day task
column2: write blot everything out .|I would forget to eat, live, and do day-to-day tasks
column3: writing blotted everything out.

column1: It sound manic , I ’ ll give you that , but it work for me because I never knew where the write journey would lead me .|It sounds manic, I’ll give you that, but it worked for me because I never knew where the writing journey would lead me.

I never have a set arc before I sat down to my laptop but found the joy partly in the process of my brain 's wander .|I never had a set arc before I sat down to my laptop but found the joy partly in the process of my brain’s wandering.

( Case in point : I stood up to write this post now , and realize I miss something I be suppose to do at 8pm… because I get lose in write . )|(Case in point: I stood up to write this post now, and realized I missed something I was supposed to do at 8pm… because I got lost in writing.)

My point be here be that the act of write be itself such a big part of what make me feel creative and alive , and it 's be very hard not to have it in my life .|My point is here is that the act of writing is itself such a big part of what makes me feel creative and alive, and it’s been very hard not to have it in my life.

I 've realize voice-to-text do not bring me the need tinglies , nor do other accommodation for my CSF leak .|I’ve realized voice-to-text does not bring me the needed tinglies, nor do other accommodations for my CSF leak.
So a I say in my 12 year of Legal Nomads post , I ’ m go to be move toward a podcast instead .|So as I said in my 12 years of Legal Nomads post, I’m going to be moving toward a podcast instead.

The podcast be go to be call Ask a Jodi , but I 've change the name to be “ The Way Through ” – because at it core , it be a podcast about get through the ups and down of life .|The podcast was going to be called Ask a Jodi, but I’ve changed the name to be “The Way Through” – because at its core, it is a podcast about getting through the ups and downs of life.
If you have topic you ’ d like me to cover , I ’ d love to hear from you !|If you have topics you’d like me to cover, I’d love to hear from you!
Email me at jodi- @ -legalnomads .com or via my contact page .|Email me at jodi-@-legalnomads .com or via my contact page.

Thus far , I have a list I 've kept from your question , which include how to be more resilient , how to be le anxious , and how to sleep well .|Thus far, I have a list I’ve kept from your questions, which includes how to be more resilient, how to be less anxious, and how to sleep better.
That 's it for now !|That’s it for now!
Thanks for all your support , love , and enthusiasm a I navigate through this complicate time .|Thanks for all your support, love, and enthusiasm as I navigate through this complicated time.
I hope you 'restay safe and well .|I hope you’re staying safe and well.
column3: Many Americans are keen to explore the world again after a year of travel restrictions.|Many Americans are keen to explore the world again after a year of travel restrictions.

column1: But a surge in demand has led to a delay in passport processing times, with some centers experiencing a turnaround time of up to 18 weeks.|But a surge in demand has led to a delay in passport processing times, with some centers experiencing a turnaround time of up to 18 weeks.

If you plan to travel soon, here's what you need to know about renewing or applying for a passport in time for your trip.|If you plan to travel soon, here's what you need to know about renewing or applying for a passport in time for your trip.

The department of state travel is advising travelers to allow up to 18 weeks to receive their passport documents and is urging the public to plan ahead and apply well before any scheduled travel.|The Department of State Travel is advising travelers to allow up to 18 weeks to receive their passport documents and is urging the public to plan ahead and apply well before any scheduled travel.

Some centers are processing passports within a 12-week timeframe but other service providers, including the us postal service, have been experiencing operational issues which the department explains is resulting in delays in applications getting to passport agencies and centers.|Some centers are processing passports within a 12-week timeframe but other service providers, including the US postal service, have been experiencing operational issues which the Department explains is resulting in delays in applications getting to passport agencies and centers.

Due to these delays, routine service can take up to 18 weeks from the day a customer submits their application to the day they receive a new passport, a department spokesperson told lonely planet.|"Due to these delays, routine service can take up to 18 weeks from the day a customer submits their application to the day they receive a new passport," a Department spokesperson told Lonely Planet.

The 18-week timeframe includes up to 12 weeks for processing and up to six weeks for mailing times.|"The 18-week timeframe includes up to 12 weeks for processing and up to six weeks for mailing times."

When applying for a new passport, it's important to note that the processing times listed on the website begin the day they receive your application, not the day you mail it.|When applying for a new passport, it's important to note that the processing times listed on the website begin the day they receive your application, not the day you mail it.

Generally, customers applying for routine service domestically can expect to receive a passport within 12 weeks from the date of application, or within six weeks from the date the application is received if they pay an additional $60 fee to expedite their passport.|Generally, customers applying for routine service domestically can expect to receive a passport within 12 weeks from the date of application, or within six weeks from the date the application is received if they pay an additional $60 fee to expedite their passport.

You can apply for a new passport through the post office, clerks of court, and public libraries but the department is encouraging applicants to renew their passports by mail when possible as a "safe, contactless option".|You can apply for a new passport through the post office, clerks of court, and public libraries but the Department is encouraging applicants to renew their passports by mail when possible as a "safe, contactless option".

In exceptional circumstances, such as cases of life-or-death emergencies and essential travel, passports can potentially be renewed within 72 hours.|In exceptional circumstances, such as cases of life-or-death emergencies and essential travel, passports can potentially be renewed within 72 hours.

However, customers must request an appointment through the department of state travel website and present proof of travel within the next three days.|However, customers must request an appointment through the Department of State Travel website and present proof of travel within the next three days.

Speaking about the reasons for delays, the department spokesperson explained "we always see an upsurge during the summer travel season.|Speaking about the reasons for delays, the Department spokesperson explained "we always see an upsurge during the summer travel season.

While this year isn’t as large as previous seasons because of the pandemic, we are still under covid-19-related staffing restrictions.|While this year isn’t as large as previous seasons because of the pandemic, we are still under COVID-19-related staffing restrictions.

We urge people not to wait to apply for a passport and apply at least six months ahead of planned travel when possible."|We urge people not to wait to apply for a passport and apply at least six months ahead of planned travel when possible."

The department is also encouraging applicants to do their research before applying for a passport through "passport expeditors" courier companies.|The Department is also encouraging applicants to do their research before applying for a passport through "passport expeditors" courier companies.

Be wary - they charge additional fees, and you will not receive your passport any faster than you would if you applied in person at a passport agency, the spokesperson warned.|"Be wary - they charge additional fees, and you will not receive your passport any faster than you would if you applied in person at a Passport Agency," the spokesperson warned.

You are still required to appear in person at an acceptance facility if applying on form ds-11 (first-time application), even when using a courier service.|"You are still required to appear in person at an acceptance facility if applying on Form DS-11 (first-time application), even when using a courier service."

Those who have only received one vaccination dose can still visit finland but they're required to take a COVID-19 test within 72 hours of departure.|Those who have only received one vaccination dose can still visit Finland but they're required to take a COVID-19 test within 72 hours of departure.

Unvaccinated tourists can also visit but they'll need to take a test before departure and a test upon arrival.|Unvaccinated tourists can also visit but they'll need to take a test before departure and a test upon arrival.

Those who can prove they have had covid-19 within the last six months and have recovered from the virus are permitted to enter without testing.|Those who can prove they have had COVID-19 within the last six months and have recovered from the virus are permitted to enter without testing.

The new measures will be reviewed every fortnight and apply to people traveling from eu and schengen countries, as well as those coming from destinations outside these zones that are classified as low-risk(where the incidence of covid-19 is low).|The new measures will be reviewed every fortnight and apply to people traveling from EU and Schengen countries, as well as those coming from destinations outside these zones that are classified as low-risk(where the incidence of COVID-19 is low).

This includes australia, hong kong, israel, china, malta, poland, new zealand and singapore among others.|This includes Australia, Hong Kong, Israel, China, Malta, Poland, New Zealand and Singapore among others.

Any other travelers must be tested for covid-19 as soon as they arrive in finland, self-isolate and take a second test between three and five days after arrival.|Any other travelers must be tested for COVID-19 as soon as they arrive in Finland, self-isolate and take a second test between three and five days after arrival.
This includes arrivals from the us and uk.|This includes arrivals from the US and UK.

The Finnish government announced on tuesday it was relaxing travel restrictions after more than a year of tight border and domestic controls to curb the spread of covid-19.|The Finnish government announced on Tuesday it was relaxing travel restrictions after more than a year of tight border and domestic controls to curb the spread of COVID-19.

Across the "world's happiest country", hotels and attractions are open and restaurants, cafes and bars are open for indoor and outdoor service.|Across the "world's happiest country", hotels and attractions are open and restaurants, cafes and bars are open for indoor and outdoor service.

Generally they can stay open until midnight but opening times can vary by region with local restrictions.|Generally they can stay open until midnight but opening times can vary by region with local restrictions.

Infections are rising in finland in recent weeks, but Reuters reports that it remains among the countries least affected by covid-19.|Infections are rising in Finland in recent weeks, but Reuters reports that it remains among the countries least affected by COVID-19.

According to the Finnish health ministry, 60% of eligible adults have received their first dose of a vaccine and 21.4% have received their second dose.|According to the Finnish health ministry, 60% of eligible adults have received their first dose of a vaccine and 21.4% have received their second dose.

amun-ra was the local god of karnak (luxor) and during the new kingdom, when the princes of thebes ruled egypt, he became the preeminent state god, with a temple that reflected his status.|Amun-Ra was the local god of Karnak (Luxor) and during the New Kingdom, when the princes of Thebes ruled Egypt, he became the preeminent state god, with a temple that reflected his status.

At the height of its power, the temple owned 421,000 head of cattle, 65 cities, 83 ships and 276,400 hectares of agricultural land and had 81,000 people working for it.|At the height of its power, the temple owned 421,000 head of cattle, 65 cities, 83 ships and 276,400 hectares of agricultural land and had 81,000 people working for it.

The shell that remains, sacked by Assyrians and Persians, is still one of the world's great archaeological sites, grand, beautiful and inspiring.|The shell that remains, sacked by Assyrians and Persians, is still one of the world's great archaeological sites, grand, beautiful and inspiring.

The quay of amun was the dock where the large boats carrying the statues of the gods moored during festivals.|The Quay of Amun was the dock where the large boats carrying the statues of the gods moored during festivals.

From paintings in the tomb of nakht and elsewhere we know that there were palaces to the north of the quay and that these were surrounded by lush gardens.|From paintings in the tomb of Nakht and elsewhere we know that there were palaces to the north of the quay and that these were surrounded by lush gardens.
On the east side, a ramp slopes down to the processional avenue of ram-headed sphinxes.|On the east side, a ramp slopes down to the processional avenue of ram-headed sphinxes.

These lead to the massive unfinished first pylon, the last to be built, during the reign of nectanebo I (30th dynasty).|These lead to the massive unfinished first pylon, the last to be built, during the reign of Nectanebo I (30th dynasty).

The inner side of the pylon still has the massive mud-brick construction ramp, up which blocks of stone for the pylon were dragged with rollers and ropes.|The inner side of the pylon still has the massive mud-brick construction ramp, up which blocks of stone for the pylon were dragged with rollers and ropes.
napoleon’s expedition recorded blocks still on the ramp.|Napoleon’s expedition recorded blocks still on the ramp.
Behind the first pylon lies the great court, the largest area of the karnak complex.|Behind the first pylon lies the Great Court, the largest area of the Karnak complex.

To the left is the shrine of seti ii, with three small chapels that held the sacred barques (boats) of mut, amun and khonsu during the lead-up to the opet festival.|To the left is the Shrine of Seti II, with three small chapels that held the sacred barques (boats) of Mut, Amun and Khonsu during the lead-up to the Opet Festival.

In the southeastern corner (far right) is the well-preserved temple of ramses iii, a miniature version of the pharaoh’s temple at medinat habu.|In the southeastern corner (far right) is the well-preserved Temple of Ramses III, a miniature version of the pharaoh’s temple at Medinat Habu.

The temple plan is simple and classic: pylon, open court, vestibule with four osirid columns and four columns, hypostyle hall with eight columns and three barque chapels for amun, mut and khonsu.|The temple plan is simple and classic: pylon, open court, vestibule with four Osirid columns and four columns, hypostyle hall with eight columns and three barque chapels for Amun, Mut and Khonsu.

At the centre of the court is a 21m column with a papyrus-shaped capital – the only survivor of ten columns that originally stood here – and a small alabaster altar, all that remains of the kiosk of taharka, the 25th-dynasty Nubian pharaoh.|At the centre of the court is a 21m column with a papyrus-shaped capital – the only survivor of ten columns that originally stood here – and a small alabaster altar, all that remains of the Kiosk of Taharka, the 25th-dynasty Nubian pharaoh.

The second pylon was begun by horemheb, the last 18th-dynasty pharaoh, and continued by ramses I and ramses ii, who also raised three colossal red-granite statues of himself on either side of the entrance
column2: one is now destroyed.|The second pylon was begun by Horemheb, the last 18th-dynasty pharaoh, and continued by Ramses I and Ramses II, who also raised three colossal red-granite statues of himself on either side of the entrance
column3: one is now destroyed.

column1: Beyond the second pylon is the extraordinary great hypostyle hall, one of the greatest religious monuments ever built.|Beyond the second pylon is the extraordinary Great Hypostyle Hall, one of the greatest religious monuments ever built.

Covering 5500 sq m – enough space to contain both rome’s st peter’s basilica and london’s st paul’s cathedral – the hall is an unforgettable forest of 134 towering stone pillars.|Covering 5500 sq m – enough space to contain both Rome’s St Peter’s Basilica and London’s St Paul’s Cathedral – the hall is an unforgettable forest of 134 towering stone pillars.
Their papyrus shape symbolise a swamp, of which there were so many along the nile.|Their papyrus shape symbolise a swamp, of which there were so many along the Nile.

Ancient Egyptians believed that these plants surrounded the primeval mound on which life was first created.|Ancient Egyptians believed that these plants surrounded the primeval mound on which life was first created.

Each summer when the nile began to flood, this hall and its columns would fill with several feet of water.|Each summer when the Nile began to flood, this hall and its columns would fill with several feet of water.

Originally, the columns would have been brightly painted – some colour remains – and roofed, making it pretty dark away from the lit main axis.|Originally, the columns would have been brightly painted – some colour remains – and roofed, making it pretty dark away from the lit main axis.

The size and grandeur of the pillars and the endless decorations can be overwhelming, so take your time, sit for a while and stare at the dizzying spectacle.|The size and grandeur of the pillars and the endless decorations can be overwhelming, so take your time, sit for a while and stare at the dizzying spectacle.
The hall was planned by ramses I and built by seti I and ramses ii.|The hall was planned by Ramses I and built by Seti I and Ramses II.

Note the difference in quality between the delicate raised relief in the northern part, by seti I, and the much cruder sunken relief work, added by ramses ii in the southern part of the hall.|Note the difference in quality between the delicate raised relief in the northern part, by Seti I, and the much cruder sunken relief work, added by Ramses II in the southern part of the hall.

The cryptic scenes on the inner walls were intended for the priesthood and the royalty who understood the religious context, but the outer walls are easier to comprehend, showing the pharaoh’s military prowess and strength, and his ability to bring order to chaos.|The cryptic scenes on the inner walls were intended for the priesthood and the royalty who understood the religious context, but the outer walls are easier to comprehend, showing the pharaoh’s military prowess and strength, and his ability to bring order to chaos.

On the back of the third pylon, built by amenhotep iii, to the right the pharaoh is shown sailing the sacred barque during the opet festival.|On the back of the third pylon, built by Amenhotep III, to the right the pharaoh is shown sailing the sacred barque during the Opet Festival.

Tuthmosis I (1504–1492 bc) created a narrow court between the third and fourth pylons, where four obelisks stood, two each for Tuthmosis I and Tuthmosis iii (1479–1425 bc).|Tuthmosis I (1504–1492 BC) created a narrow court between the third and fourth pylons, where four obelisks stood, two each for Tuthmosis I and Tuthmosis III (1479–1425 BC).
Only the bases remain except for one, 22m high, raised for Tuthmosis I.|Only the bases remain except for one, 22m high, raised for Tuthmosis I.

beyond the fourth pylon is the hypostyle hall of tuthmosis iii built by tuthmosis I in precious wood, and altered by tuthmosis iii with 14 columns and a stone roof.|Beyond the fourth pylon is the Hypostyle Hall of Tuthmosis III built by Tuthmosis I in precious wood, and altered by Tuthmosis III with 14 columns and a stone roof.

In this court stands one of the two magnificent 30m-high obelisks erected by queen hatshepsut (1473–1458 bc) to the glory of her ‘father’ amun.|In this court stands one of the two magnificent 30m-high obelisks erected by Queen Hatshepsut (1473–1458 BC) to the glory of her ‘father’ Amun.
The other is broken, but the upper shaft lies near the sacred lake.|The other is broken, but the upper shaft lies near the sacred lake.

The obelisk of hatshepsut is the tallest in egypt, its tip originally covered in electrum (a commonly used alloy of gold and silver).|The Obelisk of Hatshepsut is the tallest in Egypt, its tip originally covered in electrum (a commonly used alloy of gold and silver).

After hatshepsut’s death, her stepson tuthmosis iii eradicated all signs of her reign and had them walled into a sandstone structure.|After Hatshepsut’s death, her stepson Tuthmosis III eradicated all signs of her reign and had them walled into a sandstone structure.

The ruined fifth pylon, constructed by tuthmosis I, leads to another colonnade now badly ruined, followed by the small sixth pylon, raised by tuthmosis iii, who also built the pair of red-granite columns in the vestibule beyond, carved with the lotus and the papyrus, the symbols of upper and lower egypt.|The ruined fifth pylon, constructed by Tuthmosis I, leads to another colonnade now badly ruined, followed by the small sixth pylon, raised by Tuthmosis III, who also built the pair of red-granite columns in the vestibule beyond, carved with the lotus and the papyrus, the symbols of Upper and Lower Egypt.

Nearby, on the left, are two huge statues of amun and the goddess amunet, carved in the reign of tutankhamun.|Nearby, on the left, are two huge statues of Amun and the goddess Amunet, carved in the reign of Tutankhamun.

The original sanctuary of amun, the very core of the temple and the place of darkness where the god resided, was built by tuthmosis iii.|The original Sanctuary of Amun, the very core of the temple and the place of darkness where the god resided, was built by Tuthmosis III.

destroyed when the temple was sacked by the Persians, it was rebuilt in granite by alexander the great’s successor and half-brother, the fragile, dim-witted philip arrhidaeus (323–317 bc).|Destroyed when the temple was sacked by the Persians, it was rebuilt in granite by Alexander the Great’s successor and half-brother, the fragile, dim-witted Philip Arrhidaeus (323–317 BC).

east of the shrine of philip arrhidaeus is the oldest-known part of the temple, the middle kingdom court, where sesostris I built a shrine, of which the foundation walls have been found.|East of the shrine of Philip Arrhidaeus is the oldest-known part of the temple, the Middle Kingdom Court, where Sesostris I built a shrine, of which the foundation walls have been found.

On the northern wall of the court is the wall of records, a running tally of the organised tribute the pharaoh exacted in honour of amun from his subjugated lands.|On the northern wall of the court is the Wall of Records, a running tally of the organised tribute the pharaoh exacted in honour of Amun from his subjugated lands.
At the back of the middle kingdom court is the great festival hall of tuthmosis iii.|At the back of the Middle Kingdom Court is the Great Festival Hall of Tuthmosis III.

It is an unusual structure with carved stone columns imitating tent poles, perhaps a reference to the pharaoh’s life under canvas on his frequent military expeditions abroad.|It is an unusual structure with carved stone columns imitating tent poles, perhaps a reference to the pharaoh’s life under canvas on his frequent military expeditions abroad.

The columned vestibule that lies beyond, generally referred to as the botanical gardens, has wonderful, detailed relief scenes of the flora and fauna that the pharaoh had encountered during his campaigns in syria and palestine, and had brought back to egypt.|The columned vestibule that lies beyond, generally referred to as the Botanical Gardens, has wonderful, detailed relief scenes of the flora and fauna that the pharaoh had encountered during his campaigns in Syria and Palestine, and had brought back to Egypt.

The courtyard between the hypostyle hall and the seventh pylon, built by tuthmosis iii, is known as the cachette court, as thousands of stone and bronze statues were discovered here in 1903.|The courtyard between the Hypostyle Hall and the seventh pylon, built by Tuthmosis III, is known as the cachette court, as thousands of stone and bronze statues were discovered here in 1903.
The priests had the old statues and temple furniture they no longer needed buried around 300 bc.|The priests had the old statues and temple furniture they no longer needed buried around 300 BC.

Most statues were sent to the Egyptian museum in cairo, but some remain, standing in front of the seventh pylon, including four of Tuthmosis iii on the left.|Most statues were sent to the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, but some remain, standing in front of the seventh pylon, including four of Tuthmosis III on the left.

The well-preserved eighth pylon, built by queen hatshepsut, is the oldest part of the north–south axis of the temple, and one of the earliest pylons in karnak.|The well-preserved eighth pylon, built by Queen Hatshepsut, is the oldest part of the north–south axis of the temple, and one of the earliest pylons in Karnak.

carved on it is a text she falsely attributed to tuthmosis I, justifying her taking the throne of egypt.|Carved on it is a text she falsely attributed to Tuthmosis I, justifying her taking the throne of Egypt.

east of the seventh and eighth pylons is the sacred lake, where, according to herodotus, the priests of amun bathed twice daily and nightly for ritual purity.|East of the seventh and eighth pylons is the sacred lake, where, according to Herodotus, the priests of Amun bathed twice daily and nightly for ritual purity.

On the northwestern side of the lake is part of the fallen obelisk of hatshepsut showing her coronation, and a giant scarab in stone dedicated by amenhotep iii to khepri, a form of the sun god.|On the northwestern side of the lake is part of the Fallen Obelisk of Hatshepsut showing her coronation, and a giant scarab in stone dedicated by Amenhotep III to Khepri, a form of the sun god.

In the southwestern corner of the enclosure is the temple of khonsu, god of the moon, and son of amun and mut.|In the southwestern corner of the enclosure is the Temple of Khonsu, god of the moon, and son of Amun and Mut.

It can be reached from a door in the southern wall of the hypostyle hall of the temple of amun, via a path through various blocks of stone.|It can be reached from a door in the southern wall of the Hypostyle Hall of the Temple of Amun, via a path through various blocks of stone.

The temple, mostly the work of ramses iii and enlarged by later ramesside rulers, lies north of Euergetes’ gate and the avenue of sphinxes leading to luxor temple.|The temple, mostly the work of Ramses III and enlarged by later Ramesside rulers, lies north of Euergetes’ Gate and the avenue of sphinxes leading to Luxor Temple.

The temple pylon leads via a peristyle court to a hypostyle hall with eight columns carved with figures of ramses xi and the high priest herihor, who effectively ruled upper egypt at the time.|The temple pylon leads via a peristyle court to a hypostyle hall with eight columns carved with figures of Ramses XI and the High Priest Herihor, who effectively ruled Upper Egypt at the time.
The next chamber housed the sacred barque of khonsu.|The next chamber housed the sacred barque of Khonsu.
