This complex is studded with monuments straddling several centuries, and will be of immense interest to any history, architecture or calligraphy buffs.|This complex is studded with monuments straddling several centuries, and will be of immense interest to any history, architecture or calligraphy buffs.
The ruins continue in the neighbouring mehrauli archaeological park.|The ruins continue in the neighbouring Mehrauli Archaeological Park.

From samhain and all souls’ day to día de muertos and good old all hallow’s eve (halloween), the northern hemisphere’s autumnal shift into the long, dark days of winter turns up some creepy and colorful celebrations around the globe
column2: annual holidays that count amongst the world’s oldest and perhaps most misunderstood.|From Samhain and All Souls’ Day to Día de Muertos and good old All Hallow’s Eve (Halloween), the northern hemisphere’s autumnal shift into the long, dark days of winter turns up some creepy and colorful celebrations around the globe
column3: annual holidays that count amongst the world’s oldest and perhaps most misunderstood.

column1: Historically many cultures – from pagan and aztec to celtic – have recognised the last day of october and the first two days of november as a time when the dead were thought to return to earth and walk among the living.|Historically many cultures – from Pagan and Aztec to Celtic – have recognised the last day of October and the first two days of November as a time when the dead were thought to return to earth and walk among the living.
Afraid of ghosts?|Afraid of ghosts?
That’s what costumes, thought to ward off evil spirits, are for.|That’s what costumes, thought to ward off evil spirits, are for.

So before you write off halloween as nothing but tricks and treats for the kiddie set, why not head to a city that takes its traditions – not to mention its fun – seriously?|So before you write off Halloween as nothing but tricks and treats for the kiddie set, why not head to a city that takes its traditions – not to mention its fun – seriously?

From a new orleans moonlit cemetery tour to the flamboyant debauchery of hong kong’s hippest party district, these are five of the best halloween travel destinations.|From a New Orleans moonlit cemetery tour to the flamboyant debauchery of Hong Kong’s hippest party district, these are five of the best Halloween travel destinations.
new york city: get your groove on with the village people

Since 1973, this epic parade – rumored to be the largest Halloween celebration on earth with an estimated 2 million attendees – has remained an iconic new york moment.|New York City: get your groove on with the village people
Since 1973, this epic parade – rumored to be the largest Halloween celebration on earth with an estimated 2 million attendees – has remained an iconic New York moment.

show up early and stake out a prime spot on sixth avenue in greenwich village, where the whole city seems to converge in a true melting pot experience.|Show up early and stake out a prime spot on Sixth Avenue in Greenwich Village, where the whole city seems to converge in a true melting pot experience.

From the people watching (picture a provocative array of costumes designed to thrill, shock, and defy explanation) to phantasmagoric floats, giant puppets, live bands and circus performers, this event is an only-in-New-York madcap delight.|From the people watching (picture a provocative array of costumes designed to thrill, shock, and defy explanation) to phantasmagoric floats, giant puppets, live bands and circus performers, this event is an only-in-New-York madcap delight.
want to join in the fun?|Want to join in the fun?
This year’s themes are "let's play!"|This year’s themes are "Let's play!"
and "All together now!".|and "All together now!".

Arrive at 6pm to line up for the parade, and don’t forget your creative costume – think board games, playground games, anything interactive, along with an all-important decorative mask.|Arrive at 6pm to line up for the parade, and don’t forget your creative costume – think board games, playground games, anything interactive, along with an all-important decorative mask.

Something about the phrase día de muertos – that’s "day of the dead" in Spanish – simply rolls off the tongue with the kind of mysterious energy that this mexican cultural capital exudes.|Something about the phrase Día de Muertos – that’s "Day of the Dead" in Spanish – simply rolls off the tongue with the kind of mysterious energy that this Mexican cultural capital exudes.

held on all saints’ day (november 1) and all souls’ day (november 2) according to the catholic calendar, this aztec-influenced festival commemorates the memory of deceased family, friends, and ancestors.|Held on All Saints’ Day (November 1) and All Souls’ Day (November 2) according to the Catholic calendar, this Aztec-influenced festival commemorates the memory of deceased family, friends, and ancestors.

The festival is held in numerous cities in mexico, but is arguably at its most spectacular in oaxaca.|The festival is held in numerous cities in Mexico, but is arguably at its most spectacular in Oaxaca.

Here, the streets overflow with parades, colorful markets and costumed revelers sporting wildly macabre masks, while in nearby graveyards families spare no effort in their quest to create the most extravagantly decorated tombstones, replete with elaborate flowers and the eerie glow of countless candles.|Here, the streets overflow with parades, colorful markets and costumed revelers sporting wildly macabre masks, while in nearby graveyards families spare no effort in their quest to create the most extravagantly decorated tombstones, replete with elaborate flowers and the eerie glow of countless candles.

don’t skip a trip to a panaderia (bakery), where a mind-blowing array of morbid sweet treats will be on display.|Don’t skip a trip to a panaderia (bakery), where a mind-blowing array of morbid sweet treats will be on display.
Try a sugar-spun coffin, or the eggy, yeasty pan de muerto (bread of the dead).|Try a sugar-spun coffin, or the eggy, yeasty pan de muerto (bread of the dead).
Take the decadence and debauchery of mardi gras.|Take the decadence and debauchery of Mardi Gras.

now add a witch costume, an eerie soundtrack and a dash of voodoo magic, and you’ve got yourself a n’awlins style halloween.|Now add a witch costume, an eerie soundtrack and a dash of voodoo magic, and you’ve got yourself a N’awlins style Halloween.

With an intoxicating dark side that’s celebrated all year round, the big easy cranks up the fright factor in inimitable style come late october (and with weather that’s perfect for parading around in a daring costume).|With an intoxicating dark side that’s celebrated all year round, the Big Easy cranks up the fright factor in inimitable style come late October (and with weather that’s perfect for parading around in a daring costume).

Expect this behemoth of a shindig to last several days, with parades and parties in the streets building to a climax on october 31.|Expect this behemoth of a shindig to last several days, with parades and parties in the streets building to a climax on October 31.

For a deliciously sinful vibe, start on notorious bourbon street and strut your stuff through the heart of the vieux carré (French quarter), where an exotic spectacle of halloween fashion will be on show.|For a deliciously sinful vibe, start on notorious Bourbon Street and strut your stuff through the heart of the Vieux Carré (French Quarter), where an exotic spectacle of Halloween fashion will be on show.

From the elegant balconies, revellers toss down "treats" (mardi gras beads) to the crowds in exchange for "tricks" (usually a smile and a wave... though expect to see plenty more).|From the elegant balconies, revellers toss down "treats" (Mardi Gras beads) to the crowds in exchange for "tricks" (usually a smile and a wave... though expect to see plenty more).
Feeling adventurous?|Feeling adventurous?

head to historic jackson square to seek your fortune with a mystic, brave a moonlit cemetery tour, or dress your wicked best at the city’s sexiest party, the endless night vampire ball at the house of blues (strict costumed dress code applies!).|Head to historic Jackson Square to seek your fortune with a mystic, brave a moonlit cemetery tour, or dress your wicked best at the city’s sexiest party, the Endless Night Vampire Ball at the House of Blues (strict costumed dress code applies!).

mix plenty of international expats with a dash of local traditions, and you’ve got one of asia’s most festive halloween celebrations.|Mix plenty of international expats with a dash of local traditions, and you’ve got one of Asia’s most festive Halloween celebrations.
head to the lan kwai fong district to find the epicenter of the party-all-night action.|Head to the Lan Kwai Fong district to find the epicenter of the party-all-night action.

The restaurants and bars here are known to take their halloween decor seriously, so it’s also the perfect spot to kick off the night with atmospheric dinner and drinks.|The restaurants and bars here are known to take their Halloween decor seriously, so it’s also the perfect spot to kick off the night with atmospheric dinner and drinks.
For all-out halloween fun, you can’t do better than hong kong’s theme parks.|For all-out Halloween fun, you can’t do better than Hong Kong’s theme parks.

ocean park goes hardest on the spooky attractions, with immersive haunted experiences and scary street shows – book tickets in advance.|Ocean Park goes hardest on the spooky attractions, with immersive haunted experiences and scary street shows – book tickets in advance.
got kids in tow?|Got kids in tow?

head to hong kong disneyland, where famous disney villains, such as maleficent, jafar, cruella and captain hook, preside over the park for the night.|Head to Hong Kong Disneyland, where famous Disney villains, such as Maleficent, Jafar, Cruella and Captain Hook, preside over the park for the night.

Expect plenty of special-effects delights, from a ghostly roller coaster to show-stopping pyrotechnics designed to impress even jaded adults.|Expect plenty of special-effects delights, from a ghostly roller coaster to show-stopping pyrotechnics designed to impress even jaded adults.
Originating in druid and celtic rituals, samhain literally means "summer’s end".|Originating in Druid and Celtic rituals, Samhain literally means "summer’s end".

Drawing upon its rich celtic history (and claim to fame as the birthplace of none other than dracula author bram stoker) dublin offers a mysteriously romantic twist on the holiday.|Drawing upon its rich Celtic history (and claim to fame as the birthplace of none other than Dracula author Bram Stoker) Dublin offers a mysteriously romantic twist on the holiday.

Annual events include a carnival-style parade along with plenty of traditional bonfires around town.|Annual events include a carnival-style parade along with plenty of traditional bonfires around town.
care to mix your horror with a bit of history?|Care to mix your horror with a bit of history?

brave a haunted dublin tour or join gothic horror enthusiasts at the bram stoker festival (reopening in 2022), complete with seances, theatrical performances and outdoor film screenings.|Brave a haunted Dublin tour or join gothic horror enthusiasts at the Bram Stoker Festival (reopening in 2022), complete with seances, theatrical performances and outdoor film screenings.

For a truly otherworldly celebration with a decidedly ancient flair, don’t miss the superstition-rich festivities at the national leprechaun museum.|For a truly otherworldly celebration with a decidedly ancient flair, don’t miss the superstition-rich festivities at the National Leprechaun Museum.

Along with celtic-inspired stories and games, expect to be haunted by costumed characters straight out of Irish mythology.|Along with Celtic-inspired stories and games, expect to be haunted by costumed characters straight out of Irish mythology.

Four magnificent arches, their lintels richly decorated with crusader crosses, herald the entrance to one of christianity's most sacred sites.|Four magnificent arches, their lintels richly decorated with Crusader crosses, herald the entrance to one of Christianity's most sacred sites.

The church is believed by many Christians to be built over the biblical calvary, or golgotha, where jesus was nailed to the cross, died and rose from the dead.|The church is believed by many Christians to be built over the biblical Calvary, or Golgotha, where Jesus was nailed to the cross, died and rose from the dead.
For the past 16 centuries, pilgrims have travelled far to worship here
column2: expect crowds rather than quiet contemplation, unless you arrive early.|For the past 16 centuries, pilgrims have travelled far to worship here
column3: expect crowds rather than quiet contemplation, unless you arrive early.

column1: The easiest access is via Christian quarter rd.|The easiest access is via Christian Quarter Rd.

Tightly enclosed within a courtyard at the edge of the christian and muslim quarters, the church appears to rise out of nowhere.|Tightly enclosed within a courtyard at the edge of the Christian and Muslim Quarters, the church appears to rise out of nowhere.

It is perennially packed with tourists and pilgrims, largely because it incorporates the final five Stations of the cross (stops 10 to 14 of the via dolorosa).|It is perennially packed with tourists and pilgrims, largely because it incorporates the final five Stations of the Cross (stops 10 to 14 of the Via Dolorosa).
The 10th station of the cross is in a small chapel reached by stairs to the right of the church entrance
column2: it is believed that jesus was stripped of his garments here.|The 10th Station of the Cross is in a small chapel reached by stairs to the right of the church entrance
column3: it is believed that Jesus was stripped of his garments here.

column1: Behind the wall of the 10th station is the 11th station, where jesus is believed to have been nailed to the cross.|Behind the wall of the 10th Station is the 11th Station, where Jesus is believed to have been nailed to the cross.
The site of his death, the rock of calvary, is the 12th Station
column2: an altar has been built with a hole allowing pilgrims to touch the rock.|The site of his death, the Rock of Calvary, is the 12th Station
column3: an altar has been built with a hole allowing pilgrims to touch the rock.

column1: between the two is the 13th Station, where jesus's body is said to have been taken down.|Between the two is the 13th Station, where Jesus's body is said to have been taken down.

Back down the stairs, it's impossible to miss the rotunda housing the the 14th station, the tomb of the holy sepulchre.|Back down the stairs, it's impossible to miss the rotunda housing the the 14th Station, the Tomb of the Holy Sepulchre.

The decision to erect a church here is said to have been the result of lobbying on the part of helena, the mother of emperor constantine, 300 years after the crucifixion.|The decision to erect a church here is said to have been the result of lobbying on the part of Helena, the mother of Emperor Constantine, 300 years after the crucifixion.

While on pilgrimage in the holy city, she took note of hadrian’s pagan temple and shrine to venus (built in 135 ce), and believed it had been placed here to thwart early Christians who had worshipped at the site.|While on pilgrimage in the Holy City, she took note of Hadrian’s pagan temple and shrine to Venus (built in 135 CE), and believed it had been placed here to thwart early Christians who had worshipped at the site.

She joined the bishop of jerusalem, macarius, in petitioning the emperor to demolish the temple, excavate the tomb of christ and build a church to house the tomb.|She joined the Bishop of Jerusalem, Macarius, in petitioning the emperor to demolish the temple, excavate the tomb of Christ and build a church to house the tomb.
Excavations revealed three crosses, leading helena to declare the site as calvary.|Excavations revealed three crosses, leading Helena to declare the site as Calvary.
work on constantine’s church commenced in 326 ce, and it was dedicated nine years later.|Work on Constantine’s church commenced in 326 CE, and it was dedicated nine years later.

If you are a little confused as to why jesus is said to have been crucified in the middle of the city, bear in mind that 2000 years ago this was an empty plot of land outside the former city walls.|If you are a little confused as to why Jesus is said to have been crucified in the middle of the city, bear in mind that 2000 years ago this was an empty plot of land outside the former city walls.

From the 4th century, shrines and churches were built, occasionally destroyed by invading armies and rebuilt on the site.|From the 4th century, shrines and churches were built, occasionally destroyed by invading armies and rebuilt on the site.

When his armies took the city in 638 ce, caliph omar was invited to pray in the church, but he refused, generously noting that if he did, his fellow muslims would turn it into a mosque.|When his armies took the city in 638 CE, Caliph Omar was invited to pray in the church, but he refused, generously noting that if he did, his fellow Muslims would turn it into a mosque.
The church was later destroyed by the mad caliph hakim in 1009.|The church was later destroyed by the mad Caliph Hakim in 1009.
Restoration began in 1010 but proceeded slowly because of a lack of funds.|Restoration began in 1010 but proceeded slowly because of a lack of funds.
Eventually, the byzantine imperial treasury provided a subsidy 20-odd years later.|Eventually, the Byzantine Imperial Treasury provided a subsidy 20-odd years later.

It wasn’t enough to pay for a complete reconstruction of the original church, so a large part of the building was abandoned, but an upper gallery was introduced into the rotunda and an apse added to its eastern side as a sort of compensation.|It wasn’t enough to pay for a complete reconstruction of the original church, so a large part of the building was abandoned, but an upper gallery was introduced into the rotunda and an apse added to its eastern side as a sort of compensation.
This was the church that the crusaders entered on 15 july 1099 as the new rulers of the city.|This was the church that the Crusaders entered on 15 July 1099 as the new rulers of the city.

They made significant alterations, and so the church as it exists today is more or less a crusader structure of byzantine origins.|They made significant alterations, and so the church as it exists today is more or less a Crusader structure of Byzantine origins.

At that time, the main entrance had two access points: the current entry door and another at the head of the crusader-era staircase on the exterior, which led into a small chapel built to provide a ceremonial entrance to the site of calvary.|At that time, the main entrance had two access points: the current entry door and another at the head of the Crusader-era staircase on the exterior, which led into a small chapel built to provide a ceremonial entrance to the site of Calvary.
This chapel was walled up after the crusaders' defeat in 1187
column2: its carved lintel is now exhibited in the rockefeller museum.|This chapel was walled up after the Crusaders' defeat in 1187
column3: its carved lintel is now exhibited in the Rockefeller Museum.

column1: A fire in 1808 and an earthquake in 1927 caused extensive damage, and serial disagreements between the Christian factions who share ownership (catholic, greek orthodox, armenian orthodox, syrian, coptic and ethiopian) meant that it took until 1959 for a major repair program to be agreed upon.|A fire in 1808 and an earthquake in 1927 caused extensive damage, and serial disagreements between the Christian factions who share ownership (Catholic, Greek Orthodox, Armenian Orthodox, Syrian, Coptic and Ethiopian) meant that it took until 1959 for a major repair program to be agreed upon.

It also took decades to agree on the most recent renovations in 2016, when the tomb enjoyed a us$4 million injection of funding to stabilise the shrine.|It also took decades to agree on the most recent renovations in 2016, when the tomb enjoyed a US$4 million injection of funding to stabilise the shrine.

To avoid clashes over control of the church, the keys to it have been in the possession of the nusseibehs, thought to be the oldest muslim family in jerusalem, since the days of saladin, and it’s still their job to unlock the doors each morning and secure them again at night.|To avoid clashes over control of the church, the keys to it have been in the possession of the Nusseibehs, thought to be the oldest Muslim family in Jerusalem, since the days of Saladin, and it’s still their job to unlock the doors each morning and secure them again at night.
The church has always been home to relics, many of which have been coveted by pilgrims.|The church has always been home to relics, many of which have been coveted by pilgrims.

The cross discovered by helena was originally put on display, but it was hidden away when the temptation to take a piece as a memento (or even bite one off) became too strong for certain ardent pilgrims to resist.|The cross discovered by Helena was originally put on display, but it was hidden away when the temptation to take a piece as a memento (or even bite one off) became too strong for certain ardent pilgrims to resist.

These days, pilgrims limit themselves to pouring oil on the stone of unction and then rubbing it off on a handkerchief to take home as a relic.|These days, pilgrims limit themselves to pouring oil on the Stone of Unction and then rubbing it off on a handkerchief to take home as a relic.

Visitors here should dress modestly – the guards can be strict and refuse entry to those with bare legs, shoulders or backs.|Visitors here should dress modestly – the guards can be strict and refuse entry to those with bare legs, shoulders or backs.

The main entrance is via Christian quarter rd, but there are also entry points via dabbaga rd (accessed from souq khan al zeit st or mauristan rd) or via the rooftop Ethiopian monastery.|The main entrance is via Christian Quarter Rd, but there are also entry points via Dabbaga Rd (accessed from Souq Khan Al Zeit St or Mauristan Rd) or via the rooftop Ethiopian Monastery.

As teeming with controversy as it is with ancient history, the city of david is one of jerusalem's most active archaeological sites.|As teeming with controversy as it is with ancient history, the City of David is one of Jerusalem's most active archaeological sites.
The oldest part of jerusalem, it was a settlement during the canaanite period
column2: david is said to have captured the city and to have brought the ark of the covenant here 3000 years ago.|The oldest part of Jerusalem, it was a settlement during the Canaanite period
column3: David is said to have captured the city and to have brought the Ark of the Covenant here 3000 years ago.

column1: Excavations began in the 1850s and are ongoing, as are arguments over the development and expansion of the site which many consider to be on Palestinian lands.|Excavations began in the 1850s and are ongoing, as are arguments over the development and expansion of the site which many consider to be on Palestinian lands.
From dung gate, head east (downhill) and take the road to the right
column2: you'll find the entrance on the left.|From Dung Gate, head east (downhill) and take the road to the right
column3: you'll find the entrance on the left.

column1: At the visitors centre, you can watch a 15-minute 3D movie about the city.|At the visitors centre, you can watch a 15-minute 3D movie about the city.

There's a shop where you can buy snacks, drinks and water (in summer, you'll need it) and a pleasant patio cafe serving sandwiches, pastries and good coffee.|There's a shop where you can buy snacks, drinks and water (in summer, you'll need it) and a pleasant patio cafe serving sandwiches, pastries and good coffee.
If you intend to walk through hezekiah’s tunnel – and unless you're claustrophobic we suggest you do – you can change into a swimming costume in the bathrooms and leave your gear in a locker (10NIS)
column2: alternatively, wear shorts.|If you intend to walk through Hezekiah’s Tunnel – and unless you're claustrophobic we suggest you do – you can change into a swimming costume in the bathrooms and leave your gear in a locker (10NIS)
column3: alternatively, wear shorts.

column1: You will also need suitable footwear (strapped on sandals or waterproof shoes).|You will also need suitable footwear (strapped on sandals or waterproof shoes).

key-chain lights (5NIS) can be purchased from the ticket office, but it's better to bring a torch (flashlight).|Key-chain lights (5NIS) can be purchased from the ticket office, but it's better to bring a torch (flashlight).
Note that the entrance fee covers admission to the underground areas of the site (warren's shaft, hezekiah’s tunnel, the pool of siloam, temple road ascent)
column2: admission should be free if you only explore above-ground areas.|Note that the entrance fee covers admission to the underground areas of the site (Warren's Shaft, Hezekiah’s Tunnel, the Pool of Siloam, Temple Road Ascent)
column3: admission should be free if you only explore above-ground areas.

column1: At this active dig site with ongoing works, it can be difficult to know what you're looking at – it's definitely useful to join a guided tour.|At this active dig site with ongoing works, it can be difficult to know what you're looking at – it's definitely useful to join a guided tour.

Once you reach the bottom of the hill, you can walk the 570m back up through the temple road ascent or via the road that passes through the Palestinian village of silwan.|Once you reach the bottom of the hill, you can walk the 570m back up through the Temple Road Ascent or via the road that passes through the Palestinian village of Silwan.
Alternatively, you can take a shuttle (5NIS).|Alternatively, you can take a shuttle (5NIS).
Dramatic nighttime shows (adult/child 65/54NIS
column2: sunday, tuesday, wednesday and thursday) in the amphitheatre feature massive lights highlighting the ruins of the Royal quarter.|Dramatic nighttime shows (adult/child 65/54NIS
column3: Sunday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday) in the amphitheatre feature massive lights highlighting the ruins of the Royal Quarter.

column1: The royal quarter was first constructed in the 10th century bce, most likely as a fortification wall for a palace on the ridge.|The Royal Quarter was first constructed in the 10th century BCE, most likely as a fortification wall for a palace on the ridge.

During the First temple period an aristocrat’s home (achiel’s house) was built against the wall, but it was destroyed along with the temple in 586 bce.|During the First Temple period an aristocrat’s home (Achiel’s House) was built against the wall, but it was destroyed along with the Temple in 586 BCE.

Judean and babylonian arrowheads were found in one of the chambers, called the burnt room because of its coating of ash, vivid reminders of the bloody battle waged here.|Judean and Babylonian arrowheads were found in one of the chambers, called the Burnt Room because of its coating of ash, vivid reminders of the bloody battle waged here.

Archaeologists have also located 51 royal seals (in ancient hebrew script), including one thought to be that of the prophet jeremiah's scribe, gemaryahu ben shafan (jeremiah 36:10).|Archaeologists have also located 51 royal seals (in ancient Hebrew script), including one thought to be that of the prophet Jeremiah's scribe, Gemaryahu Ben Shafan (Jeremiah 36:10).
The seals were all located in one chamber, indicating that the room once served as an office.|The seals were all located in one chamber, indicating that the room once served as an office.

The long, sloping warren’s shaft was named after sir charles warren, the british engineer who rediscovered it in 1867.|The long, sloping Warren’s Shaft was named after Sir Charles Warren, the British engineer who rediscovered it in 1867.

The tunnel, which runs underneath the city of david to the gihon spring, allowed the canaanites to obtain water without exposing themselves to danger in times of siege.|The tunnel, which runs underneath the City of David to the Gihon Spring, allowed the Canaanites to obtain water without exposing themselves to danger in times of siege.

It’s just inside the city’s defence wall and is possibly the tunnel described in 2 samuel 5 as the means by which david’s soldiers entered and captured the city.|It’s just inside the city’s defence wall and is possibly the tunnel described in 2 Samuel 5 as the means by which David’s soldiers entered and captured the city.

Modern archaeologists, however, tend to doubt this theory, suggesting the invaders used a different tunnel.|Modern archaeologists, however, tend to doubt this theory, suggesting the invaders used a different tunnel.
From warren’s shaft, you can proceed down to hezekiah’s tunnel at the bottom of the hill.|From Warren’s Shaft, you can proceed down to Hezekiah’s Tunnel at the bottom of the hill.
The shaft closes one hour before the city of david's official closing time.|The shaft closes one hour before the City of David's official closing time.

This 500m-long underground watery passage ends at the pool of siloam, where it is said that a blind man was healed after jesus told him to wash in it.|This 500m-long underground watery passage ends at the Pool of Siloam, where it is said that a blind man was healed after Jesus told him to wash in it.

The purpose of the tunnel was to channel water flowing from the gihon spring, a temperamental source that acts like a siphon, pouring out a large quantity of water for some 30 minutes before drying up for several hours.|The purpose of the tunnel was to channel water flowing from the Gihon Spring, a temperamental source that acts like a siphon, pouring out a large quantity of water for some 30 minutes before drying up for several hours.

gihon means ‘gushing’, and the spring is the main reason the canaanites settled in the valley rather than taking to the adjacent high ground.|Gihon means ‘gushing’, and the spring is the main reason the Canaanites settled in the valley rather than taking to the adjacent high ground.
There is believed to be enough water to support a population of about 2500 people.|There is believed to be enough water to support a population of about 2500 people.

The tunnel was constructed around 700 bce by king hezekiah to bring the water of the gihon into the city and store it in the pool of siloam, thus preventing invaders, in particular the Assyrians, from locating the city’s water supply and cutting it off (an account of this is in 2 chronicles 32:30).|The tunnel was constructed around 700 BCE by King Hezekiah to bring the water of the Gihon into the city and store it in the Pool of Siloam, thus preventing invaders, in particular the Assyrians, from locating the city’s water supply and cutting it off (an account of this is in 2 Chronicles 32:30).
Although the tunnel is narrow and low in parts, you can wade through it
column2: the water is normally between 50cm and 1m deep.|Although the tunnel is narrow and low in parts, you can wade through it
column3: the water is normally between 50cm and 1m deep.

column1: The tunnel is as little as 60cm wide at some points.|The tunnel is as little as 60cm wide at some points.

About 20m into the tunnel, the cavern turns sharply to the left, where a chest-high wall blocks another channel that leads to warren’s shaft.|About 20m into the tunnel, the cavern turns sharply to the left, where a chest-high wall blocks another channel that leads to Warren’s Shaft.
Towards the tunnel’s end the roof rises.|Towards the tunnel’s end the roof rises.

This is because the tunnellers worked from either end and one team slightly misjudged the other’s level.|This is because the tunnellers worked from either end and one team slightly misjudged the other’s level.
They had to lower the floor so that the water would flow.|They had to lower the floor so that the water would flow.

A hebrew inscription was found in the tunnel (a copy can be seen in the israel museum): carved by hezekiah’s engineers, it tells of the tunnel’s construction.|A Hebrew inscription was found in the tunnel (a copy can be seen in the Israel Museum): carved by Hezekiah’s engineers, it tells of the tunnel’s construction.

The walk through hezekiah’s tunnel takes about 20 minutes (or 40 minutes if it's busy), but allow yourself plenty of time for the descent to the start and return ascent.|The walk through Hezekiah’s Tunnel takes about 20 minutes (or 40 minutes if it's busy), but allow yourself plenty of time for the descent to the start and return ascent.

If you don’t want to get wet, there's a second tunnel without water, which takes about 15 minutes to walk through.|If you don’t want to get wet, there's a second tunnel without water, which takes about 15 minutes to walk through.
To find the entrance to the dry tunnel, go left just before the opening to hezekiah’s tunnel.|To find the entrance to the dry tunnel, go left just before the opening to Hezekiah’s Tunnel.

Older children can walk through hezekiah’s tunnel, but ask about the water levels before going inside.|Older children can walk through Hezekiah’s Tunnel, but ask about the water levels before going inside.
You must begin the tunnel walk one hour before the city of david's official closing time.|You must begin the tunnel walk one hour before the City of David's official closing time.

From the byzantine pool of siloam, head up the stairs and out to an open area with crumbling steps that lead down to a small pond which is the shiloach pool.|From the Byzantine Pool of Siloam, head up the stairs and out to an open area with crumbling steps that lead down to a small pond which is the Shiloach Pool.

The pool, built during the Second temple period and used for purification rituals, was rediscovered by a bit of 'good luck' after an underground sewage pipe burst during excavations in 2004.|The pool, built during the Second Temple period and used for purification rituals, was rediscovered by a bit of 'good luck' after an underground sewage pipe burst during excavations in 2004.

Archaeologists and historians have theorised that this is the pool where jesus is said to have healed a blind man.|Archaeologists and historians have theorised that this is the pool where Jesus is said to have healed a blind man.

From the shiloach pool, head up the flight of wooden steps to the eastern stepped street, an ancient flight of stone steps.|From the Shiloach Pool, head up the flight of wooden steps to the Eastern Stepped Street, an ancient flight of stone steps.

The stair pattern – pairs of short steps with a long gap between them – is thought to have been designed for animals, so sacrifices could be led upwards with ease.|The stair pattern – pairs of short steps with a long gap between them – is thought to have been designed for animals, so sacrifices could be led upwards with ease.

A drainage ditch is located under the steps and it was here that archaeologists found roman-era coins and pottery, leading historians to believe that the ditch served as a hideout for jews while the city was being sacked in 70 ce.|A drainage ditch is located under the steps and it was here that archaeologists found Roman-era coins and pottery, leading historians to believe that the ditch served as a hideout for Jews while the city was being sacked in 70 CE.

This recently discovered 650m-long tunnel is a drainage ditch that channelled water out of the temple mount/al haram ash sharif area.|This recently discovered 650m-long tunnel is a drainage ditch that channelled water out of the Temple Mount/Al Haram Ash Sharif area.
The bottom of the tunnel is near the shiloach pool
column2: from here it’s possible to walk uphill back to the old city, exiting either into the givati parking lot site or into the davidson archaeological park and robinson's arch area (you pay extra to exit here).|The bottom of the tunnel is near the Shiloach Pool
column3: from here it’s possible to walk uphill back to the Old City, exiting either into the Givati parking lot site or into the Davidson Archaeological Park and Robinson's Arch area (you pay extra to exit here).

column1: The tunnel, directly below a herod-era road, is generally comfortably wide
column2: however, there a few narrow parts.|The tunnel, directly below a Herod-era road, is generally comfortably wide
column3: however, there a few narrow parts.

column1: The largest ongoing dig in the city of david and all of jerusalem is this massive open pit, formerly a car park, just uphill and across the street from the visitors centre.|The largest ongoing dig in the City of David and all of Jerusalem is this massive open pit, formerly a car park, just uphill and across the street from the visitors centre.

Ten years of excavations and well, you can see they've done more than scratch the surface, but there's work remaining.|Ten years of excavations and well, you can see they've done more than scratch the surface, but there's work remaining.

Layers of dirt, stones and structures read like a timeline of occupation, from biblical to second temple periods, to early and late roman, to byzantine and umayyad.|Layers of dirt, stones and structures read like a timeline of occupation, from Biblical to Second Temple periods, to early and late Roman, to Byzantine and Umayyad.

It's believed soldiers of the roman x legion were garrisoned here – roof tiles marked with their sign were found at the site.|It's believed soldiers of the Roman X Legion were garrisoned here – roof tiles marked with their sign were found at the site.

As recently as 2010, when a volunteer was digging around a niche above a doorway in the large roman villa, 264 golden coins in mint condition tumbled out.|As recently as 2010, when a volunteer was digging around a niche above a doorway in the large Roman villa, 264 golden coins in mint condition tumbled out.

Minted in jerusalem in 613 with the portrait of byzantine emperor heraclius, they now reside in the israel museum.|Minted in Jerusalem in 613 with the portrait of Byzantine emperor Heraclius, they now reside in the Israel Museum.
Archaeologists are continually piecing together clues and arguing about conclusions.|Archaeologists are continually piecing together clues and arguing about conclusions.

More than 100 pig jaws were discovered in a water cistern underneath the roman villa (which was destroyed by an earthquake in 324CE) – evidence of sacrifices?|More than 100 pig jaws were discovered in a water cistern underneath the Roman villa (which was destroyed by an earthquake in 324CE) – evidence of sacrifices?
There's evidence of a seleucid-era acropolis related to events in the book of maccabees.|There's evidence of a Seleucid-era acropolis related to events in the book of Maccabees.

controversy surrounds many of jerusalem's ancient sites, but the city of david has especially bitter points of contention.|Controversy surrounds many of Jerusalem's ancient sites, but the City of David has especially bitter points of contention.

Visitors will notice that the site feels like something of a Jewish island amid largely Palestinian neighbourhoods.|Visitors will notice that the site feels like something of a Jewish island amid largely Palestinian neighbourhoods.

The city of david is managed by elad, an organisation founded in 1986 that promotes tourism to jerusalem and funds archaeological excavations.|The City of David is managed by Elad, an organisation founded in 1986 that promotes tourism to Jerusalem and funds archaeological excavations.

The group promotes the expansion of israeli settlements into east jerusalem, so its management of the city of david has many critics.|The group promotes the expansion of Israeli settlements into East Jerusalem, so its management of the City of David has many critics.

Historians have raised doubts, too, about the objectivity with which archaeological discoveries are used to confirm biblical stories.|Historians have raised doubts, too, about the objectivity with which archaeological discoveries are used to confirm biblical stories.

Visitors may find the official narrative presented by some of the guides in the city of david to be partial and jewish-centric.|Visitors may find the official narrative presented by some of the guides in the City of David to be partial and Jewish-centric.

The givati parking lot excavation was opposed by silwan residents who argued that the 'open space' was better utilised to build schools or other public-oriented institutions.|The Givati parking lot excavation was opposed by Silwan residents who argued that the 'open space' was better utilised to build schools or other public-oriented institutions.

Since warren's rediscovery of the site around 150 years ago, around 15% of the 15-acre hill has been excavated.|Since Warren's rediscovery of the site around 150 years ago, around 15% of the 15-acre hill has been excavated.

The construction of a new seven-storey visitors centre, with an auditorium, restaurant, classrooms and parking lot, has also met vocal opposition.|The construction of a new seven-storey visitors centre, with an auditorium, restaurant, classrooms and parking lot, has also met vocal opposition.

More than 5000 years of cultural treasures are assembled around the vast israel museum's indoor and outdoor galleries.|More than 5000 years of cultural treasures are assembled around the vast Israel Museum's indoor and outdoor galleries.

Highlights are the titanic statues of the archaeological wing, while the fine arts wing showcases 20th-century israeli art from carpet weaving to sculpture.|Highlights are the titanic statues of the Archaeological Wing, while the Fine Arts Wing showcases 20th-century Israeli art from carpet weaving to sculpture.

Newcomers to Jewish culture will appreciate the rhythm of life room's lavish displays on birth, marriage and death ceremonies.|Newcomers to Jewish culture will appreciate the Rhythm of Life Room's lavish displays on birth, marriage and death ceremonies.

The prize exhibit is the Dead sea scrolls: housed in a distinctive shrine, these are among the world's oldest biblical manuscripts.|The prize exhibit is the Dead Sea Scrolls: housed in a distinctive shrine, these are among the world's oldest biblical manuscripts.

Before starting your tour (dedicate at least half a day), pick up a complimentary audio guide from the visitors centre.|Before starting your tour (dedicate at least half a day), pick up a complimentary audio guide from the visitors centre.

If you decide to spend a full day – and many visitors do – the excellent modern restaurant serves lunch.|If you decide to spend a full day – and many visitors do – the excellent Modern restaurant serves lunch.
There are also two (cheaper) cafes on-site.|There are also two (cheaper) cafes on-site.

The distinctive lid-shaped roof of this pavilion was designed to symbolise the pots in which the dead sea scrolls were kept.|The distinctive lid-shaped roof of this pavilion was designed to symbolise the pots in which the Dead Sea Scrolls were kept.

The first of the scrolls (there are more than 900 total) were found in 1947 and date back to the time of the bar kochba revolt (132–35 ce).|The first of the scrolls (there are more than 900 total) were found in 1947 and date back to the time of the Bar Kochba Revolt (132–35 CE).

Dealing with both secular and religious issues, they were thought to have been written by an ascetic group of jews called the Essenes, who inhabited the area for about 300 years.|Dealing with both secular and religious issues, they were thought to have been written by an ascetic group of Jews called the Essenes, who inhabited the area for about 300 years.

The most important is the great isaiah scroll, the largest (7.3m) and best preserved – it is reproduced in facsimile at the museum.|The most important is the Great Isaiah Scroll, the largest (7.3m) and best preserved – it is reproduced in facsimile at the museum.

The exhibit tells the story of the scrolls and the essenes and displays some of the original documents.|The exhibit tells the story of the scrolls and the Essenes and displays some of the original documents.

Forming the most extensive collection of biblical and holy land archaeology in the world, the exhibits here are organised chronologically from prehistory to the ottoman empire.|Forming the most extensive collection of biblical and Holy Land archaeology in the world, the exhibits here are organised chronologically from prehistory to the Ottoman Empire.

A group of 13th-century-BCE human-shaped clay coffins greets visitors in the first room, and other impressive displays include a 3rd-century mosaic floor from nablus depicting events in the life of achilles.|A group of 13th-century-BCE human-shaped clay coffins greets visitors in the first room, and other impressive displays include a 3rd-century mosaic floor from Nablus depicting events in the life of Achilles.

Also notable is the ‘house of david’ victory stele, a fragmentary inscription from the first temple period discovered at tel dan.|Also notable is the ‘House of David’ Victory Stele, a fragmentary inscription from the First Temple period discovered at Tel Dan.

This is the only contemporary, extra-biblical reference to the davidic dynasty to have come to light thus far.|This is the only contemporary, extra-biblical reference to the Davidic dynasty to have come to light thus far.

The standout exhibits here are four complete synagogues brought from various locations and reconstructed.|The standout exhibits here are four complete synagogues brought from various locations and reconstructed.

One, the 18th-century vittorio veneto synagogue, is adorned with gilt and plaster and was transported from italy in 1965.|One, the 18th-century Vittorio Veneto Synagogue, is adorned with gilt and plaster and was transported from Italy in 1965.
The others are from cochin, india
column2: paramaribo, suriname
column3: and horb am main, germany.|The others are from Cochin, India

column1: Also worth seeking out is the painted deller family sukkah (a temporary wooden dwelling erected during the harvest festival of sukkot), which dates from the 19th century and was smuggled from germany to jerusalem in 1935.|Also worth seeking out is the painted Deller family sukkah (a temporary wooden dwelling erected during the harvest festival of Sukkot), which dates from the 19th century and was smuggled from Germany to Jerusalem in 1935.
The rooms at the rear of the wing focus on Jewish costume and jewellery.|The rooms at the rear of the wing focus on Jewish costume and jewellery.

The highlight here is the impressionist and Post-impressionist gallery, which showcases work by renoir, pissarro, degas, sisley, monet and cézanne among many others.|The highlight here is the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist Gallery, which showcases work by Renoir, Pissarro, Degas, Sisley, Monet and Cézanne among many others.

The modern art gallery has works by schiele, rothko, motherwell, pollock, modigliani and bacon, and israeli art is well represented in the israeli art pavilion, with striking paintings by reuven rubin and yosef zaritsky.|The Modern Art Gallery has works by Schiele, Rothko, Motherwell, Pollock, Modigliani and Bacon, and Israeli art is well represented in the Israeli Art pavilion, with striking paintings by Reuven Rubin and Yosef Zaritsky.

A paved promenade leads from the shrine of the book to this sprawling sculpture garden, which was designed by Japanese artist and landscape architect isamu noguchi and includes works by 19th-, 20th- and 21st-century artists including moore, kapoor, lewitt, oldenburg, serra, rodin and picasso.|A paved promenade leads from the Shrine of the Book to this sprawling sculpture garden, which was designed by Japanese artist and landscape architect Isamu Noguchi and includes works by 19th-, 20th- and 21st-century artists including Moore, Kapoor, LeWitt, Oldenburg, Serra, Rodin and Picasso.

As teeming with controversy as it is with ancient history, the city of david is one of jerusalem's most active archaeological sites.|As teeming with controversy as it is with ancient history, the City of David is one of Jerusalem's most active archaeological sites.
The oldest part of jerusalem, it was a settlement during the canaanite period
column2: david is said to have captured the city and to have brought the ark of the covenant here 3000 years ago.|The oldest part of Jerusalem, it was a settlement during the Canaanite period
column3: David is said to have captured the city and to have brought the Ark of the Covenant here 3000 years ago.

column1: Excavations began in the 1850s and are ongoing, as are arguments over the development and expansion of the site which many consider to be on Palestinian lands.|Excavations began in the 1850s and are ongoing, as are arguments over the development and expansion of the site which many consider to be on Palestinian lands.
From dung gate, head east (downhill) and take the road to the right
column2: you'll find the entrance on the left.|From Dung Gate, head east (downhill) and take the road to the right
column3: you'll find the entrance on the left.

column1: At the visitors centre, you can watch a 15-minute 3D movie about the city.|At the visitors centre, you can watch a 15-minute 3D movie about the city.

There's a shop where you can buy snacks, drinks and water (in summer, you'll need it) and a pleasant patio cafe serving sandwiches, pastries and good coffee.|There's a shop where you can buy snacks, drinks and water (in summer, you'll need it) and a pleasant patio cafe serving sandwiches, pastries and good coffee.
If you intend to walk through hezekiah’s tunnel – and unless you're claustrophobic we suggest you do – you can change into a swimming costume in the bathrooms and leave your gear in a locker (10NIS)
column2: alternatively, wear shorts.|If you intend to walk through Hezekiah’s Tunnel – and unless you're claustrophobic we suggest you do – you can change into a swimming costume in the bathrooms and leave your gear in a locker (10NIS)
column3: alternatively, wear shorts.

column1: You will also need suitable footwear (strapped on sandals or waterproof shoes).|You will also need suitable footwear (strapped on sandals or waterproof shoes).

key-chain lights (5NIS) can be purchased from the ticket office, but it's better to bring a torch (flashlight).|Key-chain lights (5NIS) can be purchased from the ticket office, but it's better to bring a torch (flashlight).
Note that the entrance fee covers admission to the underground areas of the site (warren's shaft, hezekiah’s tunnel, the pool of siloam, temple road ascent)
column2: admission should be free if you only explore above-ground areas.|Note that the entrance fee covers admission to the underground areas of the site (Warren's Shaft, Hezekiah’s Tunnel, the Pool of Siloam, Temple Road Ascent)
column3: admission should be free if you only explore above-ground areas.

column1: At this active dig site with ongoing works, it can be difficult to know what you're looking at – it's definitely useful to join a guided tour.|At this active dig site with ongoing works, it can be difficult to know what you're looking at – it's definitely useful to join a guided tour.

Once you reach the bottom of the hill, you can walk the 570m back up through the temple road ascent or via the road that passes through the Palestinian village of silwan.|Once you reach the bottom of the hill, you can walk the 570m back up through the Temple Road Ascent or via the road that passes through the Palestinian village of Silwan.
Alternatively, you can take a shuttle (5NIS).|Alternatively, you can take a shuttle (5NIS).
Dramatic nighttime shows (adult/child 65/54NIS
column2: sunday, tuesday, wednesday and thursday) in the amphitheatre feature massive lights highlighting the ruins of the Royal quarter.|Dramatic nighttime shows (adult/child 65/54NIS
column3: Sunday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday) in the amphitheatre feature massive lights highlighting the ruins of the Royal Quarter.

column1: The royal quarter was first constructed in the 10th century bce, most likely as a fortification wall for a palace on the ridge.|The Royal Quarter was first constructed in the 10th century BCE, most likely as a fortification wall for a palace on the ridge.

During the First temple period an aristocrat’s home (achiel’s house) was built against the wall, but it was destroyed along with the temple in 586 bce.|During the First Temple period an aristocrat’s home (Achiel’s House) was built against the wall, but it was destroyed along with the Temple in 586 BCE.

Judean and babylonian arrowheads were found in one of the chambers, called the burnt room because of its coating of ash, vivid reminders of the bloody battle waged here.|Judean and Babylonian arrowheads were found in one of the chambers, called the Burnt Room because of its coating of ash, vivid reminders of the bloody battle waged here.

Archaeologists have also located 51 royal seals (in ancient hebrew script), including one thought to be that of the prophet jeremiah's scribe, gemaryahu ben shafan (jeremiah 36:10).|Archaeologists have also located 51 royal seals (in ancient Hebrew script), including one thought to be that of the prophet Jeremiah's scribe, Gemaryahu Ben Shafan (Jeremiah 36:10).
The seals were all located in one chamber, indicating that the room once served as an office.|The seals were all located in one chamber, indicating that the room once served as an office.

The long, sloping warren’s shaft was named after sir charles warren, the british engineer who rediscovered it in 1867.|The long, sloping Warren’s Shaft was named after Sir Charles Warren, the British engineer who rediscovered it in 1867.

The tunnel, which runs underneath the city of david to the gihon spring, allowed the canaanites to obtain water without exposing themselves to danger in times of siege.|The tunnel, which runs underneath the City of David to the Gihon Spring, allowed the Canaanites to obtain water without exposing themselves to danger in times of siege.

It’s just inside the city’s defence wall and is possibly the tunnel described in 2 samuel 5 as the means by which david’s soldiers entered and captured the city.|It’s just inside the city’s defence wall and is possibly the tunnel described in 2 Samuel 5 as the means by which David’s soldiers entered and captured the city.

Modern archaeologists, however, tend to doubt this theory, suggesting the invaders used a different tunnel.|Modern archaeologists, however, tend to doubt this theory, suggesting the invaders used a different tunnel.
From warren’s shaft, you can proceed down to hezekiah’s tunnel at the bottom of the hill.|From Warren’s Shaft, you can proceed down to Hezekiah’s Tunnel at the bottom of the hill.
The shaft closes one hour before the city of david's official closing time.|The shaft closes one hour before the City of David's official closing time.

This 500m-long underground watery passage ends at the pool of siloam, where it is said that a blind man was healed after jesus told him to wash in it.|This 500m-long underground watery passage ends at the Pool of Siloam, where it is said that a blind man was healed after Jesus told him to wash in it.

The purpose of the tunnel was to channel water flowing from the gihon spring, a temperamental source that acts like a siphon, pouring out a large quantity of water for some 30 minutes before drying up for several hours.|The purpose of the tunnel was to channel water flowing from the Gihon Spring, a temperamental source that acts like a siphon, pouring out a large quantity of water for some 30 minutes before drying up for several hours.

gihon means ‘gushing’, and the spring is the main reason the canaanites settled in the valley rather than taking to the adjacent high ground.|Gihon means ‘gushing’, and the spring is the main reason the Canaanites settled in the valley rather than taking to the adjacent high ground.
There is believed to be enough water to support a population of about 2500 people.|There is believed to be enough water to support a population of about 2500 people.

The tunnel was constructed around 700 bce by king hezekiah to bring the water of the gihon into the city and store it in the pool of siloam, thus preventing invaders, in particular the Assyrians, from locating the city’s water supply and cutting it off (an account of this is in 2 chronicles 32:30).|The tunnel was constructed around 700 BCE by King Hezekiah to bring the water of the Gihon into the city and store it in the Pool of Siloam, thus preventing invaders, in particular the Assyrians, from locating the city’s water supply and cutting it off (an account of this is in 2 Chronicles 32:30).
Although the tunnel is narrow and low in parts, you can wade through it
column2: the water is normally between 50cm and 1m deep.|Although the tunnel is narrow and low in parts, you can wade through it
column3: the water is normally between 50cm and 1m deep.

column1: The tunnel is as little as 60cm wide at some points.|The tunnel is as little as 60cm wide at some points.

About 20m into the tunnel, the cavern turns sharply to the left, where a chest-high wall blocks another channel that leads to warren’s shaft.|About 20m into the tunnel, the cavern turns sharply to the left, where a chest-high wall blocks another channel that leads to Warren’s Shaft.
Towards the tunnel’s end the roof rises.|Towards the tunnel’s end the roof rises.

This is because the tunnellers worked from either end and one team slightly misjudged the other’s level.|This is because the tunnellers worked from either end and one team slightly misjudged the other’s level.
They had to lower the floor so that the water would flow.|They had to lower the floor so that the water would flow.

A hebrew inscription was found in the tunnel (a copy can be seen in the israel museum): carved by hezekiah’s engineers, it tells of the tunnel’s construction.|A Hebrew inscription was found in the tunnel (a copy can be seen in the Israel Museum): carved by Hezekiah’s engineers, it tells of the tunnel’s construction.

The walk through hezekiah’s tunnel takes about 20 minutes (or 40 minutes if it's busy), but allow yourself plenty of time for the descent to the start and return ascent.|The walk through Hezekiah’s Tunnel takes about 20 minutes (or 40 minutes if it's busy), but allow yourself plenty of time for the descent to the start and return ascent.

If you don’t want to get wet, there's a second tunnel without water, which takes about 15 minutes to walk through.|If you don’t want to get wet, there's a second tunnel without water, which takes about 15 minutes to walk through.
To find the entrance to the dry tunnel, go left just before the opening to hezekiah’s tunnel.|To find the entrance to the dry tunnel, go left just before the opening to Hezekiah’s Tunnel.

Older children can walk through hezekiah’s tunnel, but ask about the water levels before going inside.|Older children can walk through Hezekiah’s Tunnel, but ask about the water levels before going inside.
You must begin the tunnel walk one hour before the city of david's official closing time.|You must begin the tunnel walk one hour before the City of David's official closing time.

From the byzantine pool of siloam, head up the stairs and out to an open area with crumbling steps that lead down to a small pond which is the shiloach pool.|From the Byzantine Pool of Siloam, head up the stairs and out to an open area with crumbling steps that lead down to a small pond which is the Shiloach Pool.

The pool, built during the Second temple period and used for purification rituals, was rediscovered by a bit of 'good luck' after an underground sewage pipe burst during excavations in 2004.|The pool, built during the Second Temple period and used for purification rituals, was rediscovered by a bit of 'good luck' after an underground sewage pipe burst during excavations in 2004.

Archaeologists and historians have theorised that this is the pool where jesus is said to have healed a blind man.|Archaeologists and historians have theorised that this is the pool where Jesus is said to have healed a blind man.

The bottom of the tunnel is near the shiloach pool

The jewel in the crown of temple mount/al haram ash sharif is the gold-plated dome of the rock, the enduring symbol of the city and one of the most photographed buildings on earth.|The jewel in the crown of Temple Mount/Al Haram Ash Sharif is the gold-plated Dome of the Rock, the enduring symbol of the city and one of the most photographed buildings on earth.
As its name suggests, the dome covers a slab of stone sacred to both the muslim and jewish faiths.|As its name suggests, the dome covers a slab of stone sacred to both the Muslim and Jewish faiths.
According to Jewish tradition, it was here that abraham prepared to sacrifice his son.|According to Jewish tradition, it was here that Abraham prepared to sacrifice his son.
islamic tradition has the prophet muhammad ascending to heaven from this spot.|Islamic tradition has the Prophet Muhammad ascending to heaven from this spot.

Only muslims can enter the temple, though modestly attired visitors of all creeds can see it from the outside as part of their walk around the plaza.|Only Muslims can enter the temple, though modestly attired visitors of all creeds can see it from the outside as part of their walk around the plaza.

The building was constructed between 688 and 691 ce under the patronage of the umayyad caliph abd al malik.|The building was constructed between 688 and 691 CE under the patronage of the Umayyad caliph Abd Al Malik.

His motives were shrewd as well as pious – the caliph wanted to instil a sense of pride in the local muslim population and keep them loyal to islam.|His motives were shrewd as well as pious – the caliph wanted to instil a sense of pride in the local Muslim population and keep them loyal to Islam.

He also wanted to make a statement to Jews and christians: islam was both righteous and all-powerful, so it could build a structure more splendid than any christian church on a location that was the location of the jewish holy of holies, thus superseding both religions.|He also wanted to make a statement to Jews and Christians: Islam was both righteous and all-powerful, so it could build a structure more splendid than any Christian church on a location that was the location of the Jewish Holy of Holies, thus superseding both religions.
malik had his byzantine architects take as their model the rotunda of the holy sepulchre.|Malik had his Byzantine architects take as their model the rotunda of the Holy Sepulchre.

But instead of the dark, gloomy interiors or austere stone facades of the Christian structures, their mosque was covered inside and out with a bright confection of mosaics and scrolled verses from the quran, while the crowning dome was covered in solid gold that shone as a beacon for islam.|But instead of the dark, gloomy interiors or austere stone facades of the Christian structures, their mosque was covered inside and out with a bright confection of mosaics and scrolled verses from the Quran, while the crowning dome was covered in solid gold that shone as a beacon for Islam.
A plaque was laid inside honouring malik and giving the date of construction.|A plaque was laid inside honouring Malik and giving the date of construction.

Two hundred years later the abbasid caliph al mamun altered it to claim credit for himself, neglecting to amend the original date.|Two hundred years later the Abbasid caliph Al Mamun altered it to claim credit for himself, neglecting to amend the original date.

briefly repurposed as a church under the Crusaders, it promptly became an islamic shrine again in the 12th century under saladin.|Briefly repurposed as a church under the Crusaders, it promptly became an Islamic shrine again in the 12th century under Saladin.

In 1545, suleiman the magnificent ordered that the much-weathered exterior mosaics be removed and replaced with tiles.|In 1545, Suleiman the Magnificent ordered that the much-weathered exterior mosaics be removed and replaced with tiles.
These were again replaced during a major restoration in the 20th century.|These were again replaced during a major restoration in the 20th century.

The original gold dome also disappeared long ago, and the dome you see today is covered with 5000 gold plates donated by the late king hussein of jordan.|The original gold dome also disappeared long ago, and the dome you see today is covered with 5000 gold plates donated by the late King Hussein of Jordan.
The 80kg of gold cost the king us$8.2 million – he sold one of his homes in london to pay for it.|The 80kg of gold cost the king US$8.2 million – he sold one of his homes in London to pay for it.
Essentially, what you see today is the building as conceived by abd al malik.|Essentially, what you see today is the building as conceived by Abd Al Malik.

inside, lying centrally under the 20m-high dome and ringed by a wooden fence, is the rock from which it is said muhammad began his miraj (ascension to heaven).|Inside, lying centrally under the 20m-high dome and ringed by a wooden fence, is the rock from which it is said Muhammad began his miraj (ascension to heaven).

According to the quran, muhammad pushed the stone down with his foot, leaving a footprint on the rock (supposedly still visible in one corner).|According to the Quran, Muhammad pushed the stone down with his foot, leaving a footprint on the rock (supposedly still visible in one corner).
Jewish tradition also has it that this marks the centre of the world.|Jewish tradition also has it that this marks the centre of the world.

Steps below the rock lead to a cave known as the well of souls, where according to medieval legends the voices of the dead are said to be heard falling into the river of paradise and on to eternity.|Steps below the rock lead to a cave known as the Well of Souls, where according to medieval legends the voices of the dead are said to be heard falling into the river of paradise and on to eternity.

The mihrab (niche indicating the direction of mecca) in the sanctuary is said to be the the oldest in the islamic world.|The mihrab (niche indicating the direction of Mecca) in the sanctuary is said to be the the oldest in the Islamic world.

note that the whole temple mount/al haram ash sharif complex is often closed to visitors during times of political unrest.|Note that the whole Temple Mount/Al Haram Ash Sharif complex is often closed to visitors during times of political unrest.

All of jerusalem meets in mahane yehuda, from first-time visitors to residents filling their trolleys with fruit and veg.|All of Jerusalem meets in Mahane Yehuda, from first-time visitors to residents filling their trolleys with fruit and veg.

Market tables are laden with wheels of halva (sesame-paste nougat), olives larger than thumbs, glistening poppy-seed pastries and almost everything that can be made or grown locally.|Market tables are laden with wheels of halva (sesame-paste nougat), olives larger than thumbs, glistening poppy-seed pastries and almost everything that can be made or grown locally.

At night, it reinvents itself as a restaurant and bar hub where local foodies and tourists hang out.|At night, it reinvents itself as a restaurant and bar hub where local foodies and tourists hang out.

The market has two major streets: mahane yehuda st, the open-air market, is more suited to loading up on produce from butchers and veg sellers, while etz chayim st, the covered market, has a proliferation of places to sample pastries, pancakes, juices and more.|The market has two major streets: Mahane Yehuda St, the open-air market, is more suited to loading up on produce from butchers and veg sellers, while Etz Chayim St, the covered market, has a proliferation of places to sample pastries, pancakes, juices and more.
A market has stood here since ottoman times.|A market has stood here since Ottoman times.

During the British mandate period, attempts to streamline its layout fell by the wayside, allowing mahane yehuda to preserve its straggling appearance to this day.|During the British Mandate period, attempts to streamline its layout fell by the wayside, allowing Mahane Yehuda to preserve its straggling appearance to this day.

Historically, the names of the market's alleyways related to the products available, but these days it's a movable feast: haafarsek (‘peach st’) has linens, hatut ('berry st') has a butcher and ha'egoz ('Walnut st') is busy with sweet, coffee and flower sellers.|Historically, the names of the market's alleyways related to the products available, but these days it's a movable feast: HaAfarsek (‘Peach St’) has linens, HaTut ('Berry St') has a butcher and Ha'Egoz ('Walnut St') is busy with sweet, coffee and flower sellers.

The market is at its bustling best on thursday and friday during the pre-Shabbat scramble, though you'll be elbow to elbow with shoppers.|The market is at its bustling best on Thursday and Friday during the pre-Shabbat scramble, though you'll be elbow to elbow with shoppers.
